TEXT.English: [TAB]Stepwells are wells in which the water can be reached by descending a set of steps. They are most common in the west of India. The main purpose of a stepwell is utilitarian, but many are elaborate architectural achievements. Many such constructions are found in Gujarat, e.g. the Rani Ki Vav built in Anhilwara (Patan) by the Solanki dynasty.

[TAB]Candis were Hindu and Buddhist temples built in Indonesia mostly between the 8th and 15th century AD. The term "candi" itself derived from Candika, one of the manifestation of the goddess Durga as the goddess of death. This suggested in ancient Indonesia the "candi" has mortuary function as well as attributed with the afterlife. The association of the name "candi", candika or durga with Hindu-Buddhist temples is unknown in India and other of Indonesia's Southeast Asian neighbours such as Cambodia, Thailand, or Burma. The historians suggested that temples of ancient Java also used to store the ashes of cremated deceased kings or royalties. This is also in-line with buddhist concept of stupa as the structure to store buddhist relicts including the ashes and remnants of holy buddhist priest or the buddhist king, the patron of buddhism. The statue of god stored inside the garbhagriha (main chamber) of the temple often modelled after the deceased king and considered as deified self of the king portrayed as Vishnu or Shiva. The example is the statue of king Airlangga from Belahan temple portrayed as Vishnu riding Garuda.[PARAGRAPH:1]Some of the more famous Candis are Borobudur, a Mahayana Buddhist monument in Central Java and the large Prambanan, dedicated to the Hindu god Trimurti, both built in the 9th century.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Ishtar Gate was the eighth gate to the inner city of Babylon. It was constructed in about 575 BC by order of King Nebuchadnezzar II on the north side of the city.[PARAGRAPH:2]Dedicated to the Babylonian goddess Ishtar, the gate was constructed of blue glazed tiles with alternating rows of bas-relief sirrush (dragons) and aurochs.[PARAGRAPH:2]The roof and doors of the gate were of cedar, according to the dedication plaque. Through the gate ran the Processional Way, which was lined with walls covered in lions on glazed bricks (about 120 of them).[PARAGRAPH:2]Statues of the deities were paraded through the gate and down the Processional Way each year during the New Year's celebration.[PARAGRAPH:2]Originally the gate, being part of the Walls of Babylon, was considered one of the Seven Wonders of the world until, in the 6th century AD, it was replaced by the Lighthouse of Alexandria.[PARAGRAPH:2]A reconstruction of the Ishtar Gate and Processional Way was built at the Pergamon Museum in Berlin out of material excavated by Robert Koldewey and finished in the 1930s. It includes the inscription plaque. It stands 47 feet high and 100 feet wide (14 meters by 30 meters). The excavation ran from 1902-1914, and, during that time, 45 feet of the foundation of the gate was uncovered.[PARAGRAPH:2]The gate was in fact a double gate. The part that is shown in the Pergamon Museum today is only the smaller, frontal part, while the larger, back part was considered too large to fit into the constraints of the structure of the museum. It is in storage.[PARAGRAPH:2]Parts of the gate and lions from the Processional Way are in various other museums around the world. Only three museums acquired dragons, while lions went to several museums. The Istanbul Archaeology Museum has lions, dragons, and bulls. The Detroit Institute of Arts houses a dragon. The Röhsska Museum in Gothenburg, Sweden, has one dragon and one lion; the Louvre, the State Museum of Egyptian Art in Munich, the Royal Ontario Museum in Toronto, the University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology in Philadelphia, the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, the Oriental Institute in Chicago, the Rhode Island School of Design Museum, the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, and the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven, Connecticut, each have lions.

A studio is an artist's or worker's workroom, or the catchall term for an artist and his or her employees who work within that studio. This can be for the purpose of architecture, painting, pottery (ceramics), sculpture, scrapbooking, photography, graphic design, filmmaking, animation, radio or television production broadcasting or the making of music. The term is also used for the workroom of dancers, often specified to dance studio.[PARAGRAPH:1]The studio of a successful artist, especially from the 15th to the 19th centuries, characterized all the assistants, thus the designation of paintings as "from the workshop of..." or "studio of..." An art studio is sometimes called an atelier, especially in earlier eras. In contemporary, English language use, "atelier" can also refer to the Atelier Method, a training method for artists that usually takes place in a professional artist's studio.[PARAGRAPH:1]The above mentioned "method" calls upon that zeal for study to play a significant role in the production which occurs in a studio space. A studio is more or less artful to the degree that the artist who occupies it is committed to the continuing education in his or her formal discipline. Academic curriculi categorize studio classes in order to prepare students for the rigors of building sets of skills which require a continuity of practice in order to achieve growth and mastery of their artistic expression. A versatile and creative mind will embrace the opportunity of such practice to innovate and experiment, which develops uniquely individual qualities of each artist's expression. Thus the method raises and maintains an art studio space above the level of a mere production facility or workshop.

[TAB]The Lubyanka is the popular name for the headquarters of the KGB and affiliated prison on Lubyanka Square in Moscow. It is a large building with a facade of yellow brick, designed by Alexander V. Ivanov in 1897 and augmented by Aleksey Shchusev in 1940-1947.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]The Lubyanka was originally built in 1898 as the Neo-Baroque headquarters of the All-Russia Insurance Company, noted for its beautiful parquet floors and pale green walls. Belying its massiveness, the edifice avoids an impression of heroic scale: isolated Palladian and Baroque details, such as the minute pediments over the corner bays and the central loggia, are lost in an endlessly-repeating classicizing palace facade, where three bands of cornices emphasize the horizontal lines. A clock is centered in the uppermost band of the facade.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Following the Bolshevik Revolution, the structure was seized by the government for the headquarters of the secret police, then called the Cheka. In Soviet Russian jokes it was referred to as the tallest building in Moscow, since Siberia could be seen from its basement. Another joke referred to the building as "Adult's World" as compared to "Children's World," the name of the popular toy store across the street.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]During the Great Purge, the offices became increasingly cramped due to staff numbers. In 1940, the most famous Soviet architect, Shchusev, was commissioned to double its size by adding another storey and engulfing backstreet buildings. Shchusev's design accentuated Neo-Renaissance detailing, but only the left part of the facade was reconstructed under his direction in the 1940s, due to the war and other hindrances. This asymmetric facade survived intact until 1983, when the symmetry was restored at the urging of Yuri Andropov in accordance with Shchusev's plans.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Although the Soviet secret police changed its name many times, its headquarters remained in this building. Secret police chiefs from Lavrenty Beria to Yuri Andropov used the same office on the third floor, which looked down on the statue of Cheka founder Felix Dzerzhinsky. A prison at the ground floor of the building figures prominently in Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's classic study of the Soviet police state, The Gulag Archipelago. Famous inmates held, tortured and interrogated there include Sidney Reilly, Raoul Wallenberg, János Esterházy and Father Walter Ciszek, S.J.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]After the dissolution of the KGB, the Lubyanka became the headquarters of the Border Guard Service of Russia, and houses the Lubyanka prison and one directorate of the Federal Security Service of the Russian Federation (FSB). In addition a museum of the KGB was opened to the public. On November 11, 1999 a fire broke out in the Lubyanka. Four FSB agents were injured, but damage was relatively mild. The fire was later traced to faulty wiring.

[TAB]The Khajuraho Group of Monuments in Khajuraho, a town in the Indian state of Madhya Pradesh, located in Chhatarpur District, about 620 kilometres (385 mi) southeast of New Delhi, is one of the most popular tourist destinations in India. Khajuraho has the largest group of medieval Hindu and Jain temples, famous for their erotic sculptures.The name Khajuraho, ancient "Kharjuravahaka", is derived from the Sanskrit words kharjura = date palm and vahaka = "one who carries". In the 19th century, British engineer T.S. Burt arrived in the area, followed by General Alexander Cunningham. Cunningham put Khajuraho on the world map when he explored the site on behalf of the Archaeological Survey of India and described what he found in glowing terms. The Khajuraho Group of Monuments has been listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, and is considered to be one of the "seven wonders" of India.

The Seven Kingdoms were also called momboares in the 17th century text of the Portuguese Jesuit priest, Mateus Cardoso, which offers an extensive description of the region. The term momboares certainly derives from the Kikongo, or Kongo language, word mbwadi, meaning seven. Cardoso noted that the region was famous in his day for the large amount of cloth that it produced, some of which was exported to the Portuguese colonial city of Luanda, Angola. Reports of the early 17th century suggest that the Seven Kingdoms exported as much as 100,000 meters of cloth annually to that market alone, suggesting that its total production must have been several times higher, putting in on a par with other major textile centers in the world, including areas of equivalent size in Europe and India.

[TAB]The Leaning Tower of Pisa, or simply The Tower of Pisa (Italian: La Torre di Pisa) is the campanile, or freestanding bell tower, of the cathedral of the Italian city of Pisa. It is situated behind the Cathedral and it is the third structure in Pisa's Campo dei Miracoli (field of Miracles). The tower is the most famous leaning building in the world. While intended to stand vertically, it began leaning to the southeast soon after the onset of construction in 1173 due to a poorly laid foundation and loose substrate that has allowed the foundation to shift.
TEXT.French: [TAB]La tour de Pise, que les Italiens appellent "torre di Pisa", est le campanile (clocher isolé) de la cathédrale de Pise, en Italie. Située derrière la cathédrale, elle est le troisième bâtiment sur la place des miracles de la ville. La tour est le plus célèbre des bâtiments penchés au monde. Verticale à l'origine, elle commença à s'incliner vers le sud-est peu après le début de sa construction en 1173, ses fondations glissant sur le sous-sol trop meuble.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der schiefe Turm von Pisa (Italienisch: La Torre di Pisa) ist ein "Campanile", ein frei stehender Glockenturm des Doms von Pisa. Er befindet sich auf der Rückseite des Doms und ist als drittes Bauwerk auf Pisas "Piazza dei Miracoli" (Platz der Wunder) das wohl bekannteste schiefe Gebäude der Welt. Das Gebäude sollte gemäß der Bauplaner normal gerade stehen, doch kurz nach Baubeginn im Jahr 1173 bekam es wegen eines Grundbruches, dem Nachgeben des Fundamentes, eine Schräglage Richtung Südosten.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]La torre pendente di Pisa, o semplicemente la torre di Pisa è il campanile della cattedrale di Pisa. Si trova dietro la cattedrale ed è la terza struttura nel Campo dei Miracoli. La torre è il più famoso edificio pendente al mondo. Pur essendo stata progettata per rimanere verticale, cominciò a pendere poco dopo l'inizio dei lavori di costruzione nel 1173, a causa di fondamenta mal realizzate e di un sottostrato friabile che ha permesso alle fondamenta di spostarsi.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]La Torre Inclinada de Pisa, o simplemente la Torre de Pisa, es una torre campanario individual de la catedral de la ciudad italiana de Pisa. Está situada detrás de la catedral y es la tercera estructura del "Campo dei Miracoli" de Pisa ("Campo de los Milagros"). La torre es el edificio inclinado más famoso del mundo. Aunque se pretendía que fuera totalmente vertical, comenzó a inclinarse hacia el sudeste poco después de su construcción, en 1173, debido a unos cimientos defectuosos y la tierra reblandecida sobre la que reposa.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Machu Picchu (Quechua: Machu Pikchu "Old Peak") is a pre-Columbian Inca city located at 2,430 m altitude on a mountain ridge above the Urubamba Valley in Peru, about 70 km northwest of Cusco. Machu Picchu is probably the most familiar symbol of the Inca Empire. It is often referred to as "The Lost City of the Incas". The site was designated as a World Heritage Site in 1983 when it was described as "an absolute masterpiece of architecture and a unique testimony to the Inca civilization".

[TAB]A charreada is a Mexican-style rodeo that is different from other rodeos. The Mexican cowboy or cowgirl is known as a charro or charra. In an American rodeo the competitors race against the clock, so the emphasis is on speed in any given event. On the other hand, in a Mexican charreada the excellent style and skills of the rider or roper are emphasized, and only one event is timed.[PARAGRAPH:1]Charrería (a word encompassing all aspects of the art) came to Mexico from Salamanca, Spain, in the 16th century. Interesting is the fact that when the Spaniards first settled in Mexico they were under the orders of the ruler to raise horses, but not to allow the Mexicans to ride them. By 1528 the Spaniards had very large cattle-raising estates. They soon found it necessary to employ the Mexicans as vaqueros or herdsman, and the natives soon became excellent horsemen. Small landholders, known as rancheros or ranchers, were the first genuine charros and invented charreadas.[PARAGRAPH:1]

[TAB]La Mezquita (Spanish for "The Mosque") of Córdoba or Cordova is a Roman Catholic cathedral originally built as a mosque in the Andalusian city of Córdoba, Spain. It is regarded as perhaps the most accomplished monument of the Umayyad dynasty of Córdoba. After the Spanish Reconquista, it was turned into a church, with a Gothic cathedral inserted into the center of the large Moorish building. Today the entire building is used to house the Cathedral of the diocese of Córdoba in Spain.[PARAGRAPH:2]The building was begun in approximately 600 A.D. as the Christian Visigothic church of St. Vincent. The first Muslim Emir Abd ar-Rahman I bought the church and reworked it over two centuries to refashion it as a mosque, starting in 784 A.D. Additionally, Abd ar-Rahman I used the mosque (originally called Aljama Mosque) as an adjunct to his palace and named it to honor his wife. According to some authors the church of St. Vincent was demolished after it was bought from the local Christian community.[PARAGRAPH:2]Several explanations have been proposed to explain the mosque's unorthodox orientation. Some have suggested the mihrab faces south because the foundations of the mosque were taken from the old Roman and Visigoth constructions. Others contend that Abd ar-Rahman oriented the mihrab southward as if he were still in the Ummayyad capital of Damascus and not in exile.[PARAGRAPH:2]The mosque underwent numerous subsequent changes: Abd ar-Rahman III ordered a new minaret; Al-Hakam II, in 961, enlarged the building and enriched the mihrab. The last of the reforms was carried out by Al-Mansur Ibn Abi Aamir in 987.[PARAGRAPH:2]It was the most magnificent of the more than 1,000 mosques in the city and was at one time the second largest mosque in the Muslim world. It was connected to the Caliph's palace by a raised walk-way, mosques within the palaces being the tradition for the Islamic rulers of all times.[PARAGRAPH:2]The city in which it was built was subject to frequent invasion and each conquering wave added their own mark to the architecture. The building is most notable for its giant arches, with over 1,000 columns of jasper, onyx, marble, and granite. These were made from pieces of the Roman temple which had occupied the site previously, as well as other destroyed Roman buildings. The double arches, pictured above, were a new introduction to architecture, and helped support the tremendous weight of the higher ceilings. The double arches consist of a lower horseshoe arch and an upper semi-circular arch. The Mezquita also features richly gilded prayer niches. A centrally located honey-combed dome has beautiful blue tiles decorated with stars. The mihrab is a masterpiece of architectural art, with geometric and flowing designs of plants. La Mezquita reached its current dimensions in 987 A.D. with the completion of the outer naves and orange tree courtyard.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1236, Córdoba was recaptured from the Muslim army by King Ferdinand III of Castile and the mosque was reconsecrated as a Christian church. Alfonso X oversaw the construction of the Villaviciosa Chapel and the Royal Chapel within the mosque. The kings who followed added further Christian features: Enrique II rebuilt the chapel in the 14th century.[PARAGRAPH:2]The most significant alteration was building a Renaissance cathedral nave in the middle of the structure. It was constructed by permission of Charles V, king of united Spain. Its reversion to a Christian church (officially the Cathedral of the Assumption of the Virgin) may have helped to preserve it when the Spanish Inquisition was most active.[PARAGRAPH:2]Artisans and architects continued to add to the existing structure until the late 18th century.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Mezquita-Catedral von Córdoba ist seit der Reconquista der Stadt deren römisch-katholische Kathedrale. Ihre architektonische Weltgeltung besitzt sie aber als ehemalige Hauptmoschee - al-Dschami? al-kabir / Dschami? Qur?uba - aus der Epoche des maurischen Spaniens. Als Kirche heißt sie Mariä-Empfängnis-Kathedrale. Mezquita ist die spanische Form des arabischen Wortes ?Masgid und entspricht dem ebenfalls gleichbedeutenden deutschen Wort Moschee. Der berühmte Betsaal ist durch Hufeisenbögen in Mittel- und Querschiffe aufgeteilt. Er wurde durch die Emire und Kalifen von Córdoba in mehreren Bauabschnitten immer wieder erweitert. Die Kathedrale von der Aufnahme Unserer Lieben Frau gehört mit ca. 23.000 m² zu den größten ehemaligen Moscheebauten weltweit.[PARAGRAPH:2]Der Ort, an dem sich die Kathedrale befindet, diente schon zu Zeiten des Römischen Reiches der Religionsausübung. Es befand sich dort ein römischer Tempel, danach eine westgotische Kathedrale für Sankt Vincent von Saragossa.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mit dem Bau der Moschee wurde 784 unter der Aufsicht von Abd ar-Rahman I., dem ersten umayyadischen Emir von Córdoba, begonnen. In den zwei folgenden Jahrhunderten wurde sie erweitert. Abd ar-Rahman III. gab ein neues Minarett in Auftrag, Al-Hakam II. erweiterte das Gebäude und stattete den Mihrab mit neuen Elementen aus. Die im Betsaal aufstehenden Säulen sind Spolien; die heute vorhandenen Bogenformen zur Hervorhebung einzelner Betsaalbereiche sind erst in der Bauphase unter Al-Hakam II. verwendet worden. Die letzten Erweiterungen wurden durch den Wesir Al-Mansur Ibn Abi Aamir 987 vorgenommen. Die Mezquita war die prächtigste der Moscheen der Stadt. Córdoba wurde in den folgenden Jahrhunderten häufig erobert, und auf jede Eroberung folgten Veränderungen der Architektur.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A noria is a machine for lifting water into a small aqueduct, either for the purpose of irrigation or, in at least one known instance, to feed seawater into a saltern.[PARAGRAPH:2]Muslim engineers used norias to discharge water into aqueducts which carried the water to towns and fields. Some of the norias used in the medieval Islamic world were as large as 20 meters in diameter, the one in Hama being a surviving example still used in modern times. It has 120 water collection compartments and could raise as much as 95 litres of water per minute.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine Noria ist ein in Syrien gebräuchliche Form des Wasserschöpfrads.[PARAGRAPH:2]Die berühmten Wasserschöpfräder (Norias) in Hama in Syrien gelten als die größten der Welt. Sie überwinden mit entsprechend großen Raddurchmessern Höhenunterschiede von z. T. über 30 Metern. Die Wasserkunst von Mértola in Portugal hatte vermutlich ein Schöpfrad von 24 m Durchmesser.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A triumphal arch is a structure in the shape of a monumental archway, usually built to celebrate a victory in war. The arch is invariably a free-standing structure, quite separate from city gates or walls. In its simplest form a triumphal arch consists of two pillars connected by an arch, crowned with a superstructure or attic on which a statue or commemorative inscriptions might be mounted. More elaborate triumphal arches have flanking subsidiary archways, typically a pair. Famous arches include the Arch of Titus in Rome and the Arc de Triomphe in Paris.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Un arc de triomphe est un ouvrage en forme d'arche monumentale, généralement construit pour célébrer une victoire à la guerre. L'arc est toujours une structure indépendante, à l'écart des portes et des remparts de la ville. Dans sa forme la plus simple, l'arc de triomphe se compose de deux piliers reliés par un arc et surmontés d'un entablement ou d'un attique sur lequel peuvent être ajoutées une statue ou des inscriptions commémoratives. Les arcs de triomphe plus élaborés comportent des arches secondaires - généralement au nombre de deux - sur les côtés. Parmi les arcs de triomphes les plus célèbres, on trouve l'Arc de Titus à Rome et l'Arc de triomphe de l'Etoile à Paris.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ein Triumphbogen ist ein frei stehendes Bauwerk in Form eines monumentalen Tors oder Bogengangs, das üblicherweise zur Würdigung eines bedeutenden militärischen Sieges abseits von Stadttoren oder -mauern errichtet wird. In seiner einfachsten Form besteht ein Triumphbogen aus zwei Säulen, die durch einen Bogen verbunden und mit einer Attika versehen sind, auf der eine Statue thront oder eine Inschrift angebracht ist. Aufwändiger gearbeitete Triumphbögen haben zusätzlich noch angrenzende Seitenbogengänge, die meist paarweise angeordnet sind. Berühmte Triumphbögen sind beispielsweise der Titusbogen in Rom und der Arc de Triomphe in Paris.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Un arco di trionfo è una struttura con la forma di una monumentale arcata, spesso costruita per celebrare la vittoria in una guerra. L'arco è invariabilmente una struttura a sé stante, separata dalle mura o dalle porte di una città. Nella sua forma più semplice un arco di trionfo consiste di due colonne unite da un arco, sovrastato da una struttura o un attico su cui si possono trovare statue o iscrizioni. Gli archi di trionfo più elaborati possono avere arcate sussidiarie laterali, di solito una coppia. Tra i più famosi sono l'Arco di Tito a Roma e l'Arco di Trionfo a Parigi.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Un Arco de Triunfo es una enorme arcada monumental que se suele construir para celebrar una victoria en la guerra. El arco siempre es una estructura solitaria, separada de las puertas o muros de la ciudad. En su forma más sencilla consiste en dos pilares conectados por un arco que a su vez está coronado por una estructura superior en la cual se suele colocar una estatua o una inscripción conmemorativa. Los Arcos de Triunfo más elaborados pueden tener un par de arcos secundarios en los laterales. Los más famosos son el Arco de Tito en Roma y el Arco del Triunfo de Paris.

TEXT.English: [TAB]An Olympic Park is a venue set up when a country hosts the Olympic Games. A cauldron is always built within the park and it's the final destination of the torch relay ceremony. The final bearer of the torch runs towards the cauldron, usually placed at the top of a grand staircase, and then uses the torch to start the flame in the stadium. The cauldron and the pedestal it sits on are always the subject of unique and often dramatic design. These also tie in with how the cauldron is lit during the Opening Ceremony. In Barcelona in 1992, an archer shot a flaming arrow immediately over the cauldron to light it.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Un parc olympique est un lieu créé lorsqu'un pays accueille les jeux olympiques. Une vasque est toujours construite à l'intérieur du parc ; elle est la destination finale de la cérémonie de relais de la flamme olympique. Le dernier porteur de la torche court vers la vasque, généralement placée en haut d'un grand escalier, puis utilise la torche pour allumer la flamme dans le stade. La vasque et le piédestal sur lequel elle est posée ont toujours une forme unique et spectaculaire, qui déterminera comment sera allumée la vasque durant la cérémonie d'ouverture. A Barcelone en 1992, un archer a allumé la vasque en tirant une flèche enflammée juste au-dessus.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Ein Olympiapark ist ein Veranstaltungsort, der von dem Gastgeberland Olympischer Spiele errichtet wird. Im Innern des Parks ist stets eine große Schale untergebracht, welche als letzte Station für die Zeremonie des Olympischen Fackellaufs dient: Der Schlussläufer läuft auf diese Schale zu, die üblicherweise am oberen Ende einer großen Treppe platziert ist, und entzündet im Stadion das Olympische Feuer. Die Schale und das Podest, auf dem sie angebracht ist, sind stets in einem einzigartigen und häufig dramatischen Design entworfen, das thematisch die Art und Weise widerspiegelt, wie das Feuer während der Eröffnungsfeier entfacht wird - bei den Olympischen Spielen in Barcelona 1992 schoss ein Bogenschütze einen brennenden Pfeil direkt über den Kessel, um ihn zu entzünden.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Un Parco olimpico è un complesso architettonico creato da un paese quando deve ospitare le Olimpiadi e al cui interno viene sempre costruito un braciere: la destinazione della fiamma olimpica. L'ultimo tedoforo corre verso il braciere, solitamente posto in cima a una grande scalinata, e poi usa la torcia per accendere la fiamma nello stadio. Il braciere e il piedistallo su cui riposa sono sempre oggetto di design molto particolari. Ciò è anche legato al modo in cui il braciere viene acceso durante la cerimonia d'apertura. A Barcellona nel 1992, per esempio, un arciere scoccò una freccia incendiaria sopra il braciere, per accenderlo.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Un estadio olímpico es el edificio principal de acogida al público de unos Juegos Olímpicos. Siempre se construye un pebetero en el interior del mismo, que es el destino final de la ceremonia de entrega de la antorcha. El último portador de la antorcha debe correr hacia el pebetero, que suele encontrarse en la cima de unas escaleras, y usar la citada antorcha para encender la llama del estadio. El pebetero y el pedestal que lo soporta siempre son objeto de una ceremonia única y a menudo impresionante. El protagonismo de este evento también reside en el modo de pasar la llama al pebetero durante la ceremonia de inauguración. En Barcelona en 1992, un arquero disparó una flecha en llamas que inmediatamente encendió la llama del pebetero.

TEXT.English: According to Pliny the Elder, Phoenician traders were the first to stumble upon glass manufacturing techniques at the site of the Belus River. Georgius Agricola, in De re metallica, reported a traditional serendipitous "discovery" tale of familiar type:[PARAGRAPH:1]"The tradition is that a merchant ship laden with nitrum being moored at this place, the merchants were preparing their meal on the beach, and not having stones to prop up their pots, they used lumps of nitrum from the ship, which fused and mixed with the sands of the shore, and there flowed streams of a new translucent liquid, and thus was the origin of glass."[PARAGRAPH:1]This account is more a reflection of Roman experience of glass production, however, as white silica sand from this area was used in the production of glass within the Roman Empire due to its low impurity levels.[PARAGRAPH:1]During the 1st century BC glass blowing was discovered on the Syro-Palestinian coast, revolutionizing the industry. Glass vessels were now inexpensive compared to pottery vessels. A growth of the use of glass products occurred throughout the Roman world. Glass became the Roman plastic, and glass containers produced in Alexandria spread throughout the Roman Empire. With the discovery of clear glass (through the introduction of manganese dioxide), by glass blowers in Alexandria circa 100 AD, the Romans began to use glass for architectural purposes. Cast glass windows, albeit with poor optical qualities, began to appear in the most important buildings in Rome and the most luxurious villas of Herculaneum and Pompeii. Over the next 1,000 years glass making and working continued and spread through southern Europe and beyond.

A sejmik was a name of various local parliaments throughout the history of Poland. The first sejmiks were regional assemblies in the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth, and earlier in the Kingdom of Poland. Sejmiks existed until the end of the Commonwealth in 1795 following the partitions of the Commonwealth. In a limited form, some sejmiks existed in partitioned Poland, and later, in the Second Polish Republic. In modern Poland, since 1999, the term has been revived as a voivodeship sejmik (sejmik województwa), referring to the elected council of each of the 16 voivodeships.

[TAB]The Porcelain Tower (or Porcelain Pagoda) is a historical site located on the south bank of the Yangtze in Nanjing, China. It was a pagoda constructed in the 15th century during the Ming Dynasty, but was mostly destroyed in the 19th century during the course of the Taiping Rebellion. There is purportedly a movement underway to reconstruct the tower. As of 2010, reconstruction of the tower and temple grounds went underway. The projected completion date of the first phase of reconstruction is 2014.[PARAGRAPH:2]The original blocks of the Nanjing Tower's arched door, now pieced back together and on display at the Nanjing Museum [NEWLINE][TAB]The Porcelain Tower of Nanjing was designed during reign of the Yongle Emperor (r. 1402-1424) shortly before its construction, in the early 15th century. It was first discovered by the Western world when European travelers like Johan Nieuhof visited it, sometimes listing it as one of the Seven Wonders of the World. After this exposure to the outside world, the tower was seen as a national treasure to both locals and other cultures around the world.[NEWLINE][TAB]In 1801, the tower was struck by lightning and the top three stories were knocked off, but it was soon restored. The 1843 book The Closing Events of the Campaign in China by Granville Gower Loch contains a detailed description of the tower as it existed in the early 1840s. In the 1850s, the area surrounding the tower erupted in civil war as the Taiping Rebellion reached Nanjing and the Taiping Rebels took over the city. They smashed the Buddhist images and destroyed the inner staircase to deny the Qing enemy an observation platform. American sailors reached the city in May 1854 and visited the hollowed tower. In 1856, the Taiping destroyed the tower in order to prevent a hostile faction from using it to observe and shell the city. After this point, the tower's remnants were forgotten and it lay dormant until a recent surge to try to rebuild the landmark.[PARAGRAPH:2]The original blocks of the Nanjing Tower's arched door, now pieced back together and on display at the Nanjing Museum [NEWLINE][TAB]The tower was octagonal with a base of about 97 feet (30 m) in diameter. When it was built, the tower was one of the largest buildings in China, rising up to a height of 260 feet (79 m) with nine stories and a staircase in the middle of the pagoda, which spiraled upwards for 184 steps. The top of the roof was marked by a golden pineapple. There were originally plans to add more stories, according to an American missionary who in 1852 visited Nanjing. There are only a few Chinese pagodas that surpass its height, such as the still existent 275-foot-tall (84 m) 11th-century Liaodi Pagoda in Hebei or the no longer existent 330-foot-tall (100 m) 7th-century wooden pagoda of Chang'an.[NEWLINE][TAB]The tower was built with white porcelain bricks that were said to reflect the sun's rays during the day, and at night as many as 140 lamps were hung from the building to illuminate the tower. Glazes and stoneware were worked into the porcelain and created a mixture of green, yellow, brown and white designs on the sides of the tower, including animals, flowers and landscapes. The tower was also decorated with numerous Buddhist images.

[TAB]All Saints' Church is a Lutheran church in the town of Wittenberg in Germany. It is best known as the location where Martin Luther started the Reformation, by nailing his Ninety-Five Theses to the doors of the church. The Ninety-Five Theses were an attack on the sale of indulgences by the Catholic Church. "Indulgences" were purchased by those Catholics who, having already obtained forgiveness for their sins, wished to reduce the time they would spend in punishment in the afterlife for their sins, before eventually going to heaven. In practice, these were sold to fund the expenses of the Catholic Church on salaries and construction projects. It was Luther's contention that this turned penitence into a commercial transaction. [PARAGRAPH:2]Past heresies in Christianity were quickly quashed by the Church, which excommunicated and even declared crusades against dissenters. However, the development of the printing press ensured the rapid spread of Luther's message throughout Europe. Luther's refusal to recant his condemnations of Rome is seen as the beginning of the process of the Protestant Reformation.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Selon la tradition juive, le Temple de Salomon est la première synagogue de Jérusalem et en tant que "maison de Dieu", l'édifice le plus important de la religion juive. Sa construction commence sous le règne du roi David et s'achève sous celui de son fils, Salomon. Le Temple de Salomon est construit par des ouvriers phéniciens qui utilisent les plus beaux matériaux disponibles : des pierres extraites de carrières situées sous la ville, du bois du Liban, 3 000 tonnes d'or et 30 000 tonnes d'argent. Il en résulte un édifice d'une beauté surprenante mesurant près de 27 m de long, 9 m de large et 14 m de haut. Sa construction nécessite sept années. [PARAGRAPH:2] Le Temple de Salomon consiste en trois pièces principales entourées de salles plus petites. Après avoir monté quelques marches, le visiteur entre dans le vestibule, surmonté de deux énormes piliers portant les noms de Yachin et Boaz. De là, le visiteur pénètre dans la "grande maison" ou "lieu saint", où s'effectuent les principaux services religieux. Après la grande maison se trouve le "Saint des Saints", une pièce carrée lambrissée de bois de cèdre qui abrite l'"Arche d'alliance". L'Arche d'alliance est un coffre sacré qui contient les tablettes de pierre sur lesquelles sont écrits les Dix commandements que Moïse a reçu de Dieu. Le bâtiment est entouré d'une cour dans laquelle la population pratique sa religion. [PARAGRAPH:2] Le Temple de Salomon a fait l'objet de nombreux pillages au fil des années avant d'être pillé une dernière fois et entièrement brûlé par le roi Nabuchodonosor II de Babylone vers 580 av. J.-C. pendant la période de "captivité babylonienne". Des années plus tard, bon nombre des trésors du Temple de Salomon sont rendus aux juifs par le roi [LINK=LEADER_CYRUS]Cyrus[\LINK] Ier de Perse, mais il manque l'Arche. Certains pensent que l'Arche a été enlevée et cachée avant l'attaque babylonienne ; d'autres estiment que l'Arche a été prise par Babylone puis détruite ou perdue. L'Eglise orthodoxe d'Ethiopie assure qu'elle possède l'Arche qui lui aurait été apportée par l'un des fils de Salomon. En tout cas, le Temple de Salomon a été entièrement détruit et son emplacement d'origine fait l'objet de nombreuses controverses et discussions. [PARAGRAPH:2]Le "Second Temple", construit à Jérusalem vers 500 av. J.-C., est détruit à son tour par les Romains en 70 ap. J.-C. Il en reste uniquement le "Mur occidental", plus connu sous le nom de "Mur des lamentations".
TEXT.German: [TAB]Laut der jüdischen Überlieferung war Salomons Tempel der erste jüdische Tempel in Jerusalem und als "Wohnstätte Gottes" das wichtigste Gebäude des Judentums. König David begann mit dem Bau, der von seinem Sohn Salomon schließlich vollendet wurde. Der Tempel wurde von phönizischen Arbeitern aus Steinquadern, libanesischem Holz, 3000 Tonnen Gold und 3000 Tonnen Silber errichtet. Nach seiner Fertigstellung war der prächtige Tempel 30 Meter lang, 10 Meter breit und 16 Meter hoch. Der Bau des Gotteshauses nahm sieben Jahre in Anspruch.[PARAGRAPH:2]Der Tempel bestand aus drei Haupträumen und war an drei Seiten von Seitenzimmern umgeben, in denen die Schätze und religiösen Artefakte des Tempels aufbewahrt wurden. Die Vorhalle wurde von den beiden Bronzesäulen Iachin und Boas ("Festigkeit und Stärke") getragen. Die Vorhalle mündete in das so genannte "Heilige", in dem die goldenen Leuchter, der Schaubrottisch und der Räucheraltar standen. Hinter einem Vorhang befand sich das Allerheiligste mit der Bundeslade und den beiden Cherubim. Beide Räume waren mit Zedernholz getäfelt. Die Bundeslade war eine mit Gold überzogene Truhe aus Akazienholz, in der die zehn Gebote, die Moses von Gott erhalten hatte, aufbewahrt wurden. [PARAGRAPH:2]Der Tempel wurde zu Beginn der babylonischen Gefangenschaft im Jahr 586 vor Christus von den Babyloniern unter König Nebukadnezar II. geplündert und niedergebrannt. Viele Jahre später gab König [LINK=LEADER_CYRUS]Kyrus[\LINK]. von Persien den Juden den Großteil der Tempelschätze zurück. Die Bundeslade blieb jedoch verschwunden. Bis heute ist unklar, ob die Bundeslade vor dem Angriff der Babylonier versteckt oder von diesen erbeutet und zerstört wurde. Nach der Überlieferung der äthiopischen Kirche wurde die Bundeslade gestohlen und befindet sich heute in Aksum, der heiligen Stadt Äthiopiens. Da der Tempel völlig zerstört wurde, ist bis heute nicht eindeutig geklärt, wo er gestanden hat. [PARAGRAPH:2]Der "Zweite Tempel" wurde etwa um 500 vor Christus in Jerusalem gebaut und 70 vor Christus von den Römern zerstört. Alles, was von ihm noch übrig ist, ist die westliche "Klagemauer".
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Secondo la tradizione Ebraica, il Tempio di Salomone fu il primo tempio Giudaico di Gerusalemme e il "luogo di residenza di Dio", l'edificio più importante della religione israelita. La costruzione venne iniziata da re Davide e completata da suo figlio, Salomone. Il tempio venne realizzato dai lavoratori Fenici usando i migliori materiali disponibili: pietre scavate dal sottosuolo della città, legno proveniente dal Libano, 3.000 tonnellate d'oro e 30.000 di argento. Il risultato di tali sforzi fu un bellissimo tempio lungo 27 metri, largo 10 e alto 15. Per completare il tempio ci vollero sette anni.[PARAGRAPH:2]Il tempio era composto da tre stanze principali, circondate da altre più piccole. Salendo una rampa di scale, il visitatore poteva raggiungere il vestibolo che si trovava in cima a due grosse colonne Jachin e Boaz. Da qui si poteva procedere nella "casa maggiore" o "luogo sacro", dove venivano officiati importanti servizi. Dietro la "casa maggiore" si trova il "Sancta Santorum" una stanza quadrata con presente dei cedri all'interno della quale veniva conservata l'Arca dell'Alleanza. L'Arca dell'Alleanza era un contenitore sacro che conteneva i resti delle tavole sulle quali furono scritti i Dieci Comandamenti che Dio diede a Mosè: l'edificio era circondato da un cortile all'interno del quale i fedeli potevano pregare. [PARAGRAPH:2]Il tempio venne saccheggiato molte volte nel corso dei secoli e infine raso al suolo dal re Nabucodonosor II di Babilonia intorno al 580 d. C. durante "l'esilio dei Giudei a Babilonia". Anni dopo, il tesoro venne restituito da re [LINK=LEADER_CYRUS]Ciro[\LINK] di Persia, ma mancava l'Arca. Alcuni credono che l'Arca sia stata rimossa e nascosta prima dell'attacco dei Babilonesi, mentre altri credono che sia stata rubata e poi successivamente distrutta. La chiesa Ortodossa Etiope dichiara di possedere l'Arca, consegnata loro da uno dei figli di Salomone. In ogni caso, la distruzione del Tempio fu totale e si discute molto sulla destino dell'Arca. [PARAGRAPH:2]Il "secondo Tempio" fu costruito a Gerusalemme circa nel 500 a. C. per essere poi distrutto dai Romani nel 70 d. C. Tutto ciò che rimane del Tempio è il "muro occidentale", noto anche come "muro del pianto".
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Según la tradición judía, el Templo de Salomón fue el primer templo judío de Jerusalén y, como "morada de Dios", el edificio más importante de la religión judía. Las obras se iniciaron en tiempos del rey David y se concluyeron en la época de su hijo, Salomón. El templo fue levantado por trabajadores fenicios, que emplearon los mejores materiales disponibles: piedras de las canteras de la ciudad, madera del Líbano, 3.000 toneladas de oro y otras 30.000 de plata. El resultado fue un edificio de extraordinaria belleza, de unos 30 metros de largo por 10 de ancho y 16 de altura. Tardó siete años en completarse.[PARAGRAPH:2]El Templo estaba formado por tres habitaciones principales, rodeadas por cámaras de menor tamaño. Tras subir las escaleras, el visitante accedía al vestíbulo, sustentado por dos enormes pilares, conocidos como Jachin y Boaz. Desde allí podía pasar a la "Casa Mayor" o "Lugar Sagrado", donde se llevaban a cabo importantes ceremonias religiosas. Más allá de la Casa Mayor se encontraba la "Sagrada de las Sagradas", una sala cuadrada forrada de cedro que contenía el "Arca de la Alianza". El Arca era un contenedor sagrado que albergaba las diez tablas de piedra en las que estaban escritos los Diez Mandamientos, entregados a Moisés por Dios. El edificio estaba rodeado por un patio en el que el pueblo celebraba sus ceremonias. [PARAGRAPH:2]A lo largo de los años, el templo sufrió numerosos saqueos, hasta que finalmente fue incendiado y destruido por el rey Nabucodonosor II de Babilonia alrededor del año 580 a. C., durante el tiempo del "cautiverio babilónico". Muchos años después, gran parte de los tesoros del templo fueron devueltos a los judíos por el rey [LINK=LEADER_CYRUS]Ciro[\LINK] de Persia, aunque el Arca no estaba entre ellos. Algunos creen que la escondieron antes del ataque babilónico, mientras que, para otros, fue capturada por los invasores, y luego se perdió o fue destruida. La Iglesia Ortodoxa de Etiopía asegura que posee el Arca auténtica, llevada allí por uno de los Hijos de Salomón. En cualquier caso, la destrucción del templo fue total, y ha habido grandes controversias y debates sobre el lugar de su emplazamiento original. [PARAGRAPH:2]El "Segundo Templo" de Jerusalén se construyó aproximadamente en el año 500 a. C. Fue destruido por los romanos en el año 70 d. C. Lo único que queda de él es el muro occidental, también conocido como "Muro de las Lamentaciones".

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Red Fort, or Lal Qila, is a 17th century fort complex constructed by the Mughal emperor Shah Jahan in the walled city of Old Delhi (in present day Delhi, India). Shah Jahan moved his capital here from Agra in a move designed to bring prestige to his reign, and to provide ample opportunity to apply his ambitious building schemes and interests. It served as the capital of the Mughals until 1857, when Mughal emperor Bahadur Shah Zafar was exiled by the British Indian government. [PARAGRAPH:1]Shah Jahan started construction of the massive fort in 1638 and work was completed in 1648. The Red Fort was originally referred to as "Qila-i-Mubarak" (the blessed fort), because it was the residence of the royal family. The layout of the Red Fort was organised to retain and integrate this site with the Salimgarh Fort. The fortress palace was an important focal point of the medieval city of Shahjahanabad. The planning and aesthetics of the Red Fort represent the zenith of Mughal creativity which prevailed during the reign of Emperor Shah Jahan.

[TAB]San Marco Basilica, the cathedral church of Venice, is the most famous of the city's churches and one of the best known examples of Byzantine architecture. It lies on Piazza San Marco adjacent and connected to the Doge's Palace. Originally it was the "chapel" of the Venetian rulers, and not the city's cathedral. Since 1807 it has been the seat of the Patriarch of Venice, archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Venice. For its opulent design, gilded Byzantine mosaics, and its status as a symbol of Venetian wealth and power, from the 11th century on the building was known by the nickname Chiesa d'Oro (Church of gold).[PARAGRAPH:2]The first San Marco's was a temporary building in the Doge's Palace, constructed in 828, when Venetian merchants stole the supposed relics of San Marco the Evangelist from Alexandria. This was replaced by a new church on its present site in 832; from the same century dates the first San Marco's Campanile (bell tower). The new church was burned in a rebellion in 976, rebuilt in 978 and again to form the basis of the present basilica since 1063. The basilica was consecrated in 1094, the same year in which the body of San Marco was supposedly rediscovered in a pillar by Vitale Faliero, doge at the time. The building also incorporates a low tower (now housing San Marco's Treasure), believed by some to have been part of the original Doge's Palace. Within the first half of the 13th century the narthex and the new façade were constructed, most of the mosaics were completed and the domes were covered with higher wooden, lead-covered domes in order to blend in with the Gothic architecture of the redesigned Doge's Palace.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Markusdom (italienisch Basilica di San Marco) in Venedig war bis 1797 das zentrale Staatsheiligtum der Republik Venedig und ist seit 1807 die Kathedrale des Patriarchen von Venedig. Er befindet sich am Markusplatz im Stadtsechstel San Marco.[PARAGRAPH:2]Bis zum Untergang der Republik war es erklärte Absicht der venezianischen Regierung durch die Jahrhunderte hindurch, den Sitz des Bischofs möglichst weit entfernt vom Zentrum der Macht zu wissen. San Marco dagegen war die Palastkapelle des Dogen, später Staatskirche Venedigs. Sie wurde erbaut als würdige Ruhestätte für die Gebeine des Evangelisten Markus, des Stadtheiligen Venedigs, der den heiligen Theodor als Stadtpatron ablöste. Der Bischofspalast und der Bischofssitz des Patriarchen von Venedig befanden sich bis zur Säkularisierung in dem abgelegenen Distrikt von San Pietro di Castello.[PARAGRAPH:2]Die erste dem heiligen Markus geweihte Kirche wurde 828 gestiftet und in den Jahren 829 bis 832 anstelle einer Hauskapelle des Dogenpalastes erbaut, um die aus Alexandria durch eine List venezianischer Kaufleute entführten Gebeine des Evangelisten Markus aufzunehmen. 976 fielen Kirche, Dogenpalast und 200 Häuser einer Feuersbrunst zu Opfer. Im selben Jahr begann der Doge Pietro I. Orseolo mit dem Wiederaufbau, der nach mehrmaligen Unterbrechungen erst 1094 beendet war. Die (angeblichen) Gebeine des Hl. Markus wurden durch ein (angebliches) Wunder am 25. Juni 1094 "wiedergefunden". Dieser Tag wurde zum Feiertag Inventio Sancti Marci.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Interpol (or International Criminal Police Organization) was created in 1923 to assist international criminal police cooperation. Interpol, once merely the organization's telegraphic address, was officially incorporated as the organization's new name in 1956, prior to which it was known as the International Criminal Police Commission. Interpol is the world's third largest international organization, after the United Nations and FIFA; it currently has 186 member countries.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Interpol (abréviation de l'anglais "International Criminal Police Organization") fut créée en 1923 pour faciliter la coopération policière internationale. Interpol n'était au départ que l'adresse télégraphique de l'organisation. C'est en 1956 que ce nom devint officiellement celui de l'organisation, appelée jusque-là International Criminal Police Commission. Interpol est la troisième plus grande organisation internationale, derrière l'ONU et la FIFA. Elle compte actuellement 186 pays membres.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Interpol (früher offiziell "International Criminal Police Commission", zu Deutsch: Internationale kriminalpolizeiliche Organisation (IKPO)) wurde 1923 als Kommission zur gemeinschaftlichen internationalen Verbrechensbekämpfung gegründet. Das Wort "Interpol" war ursprünglich lediglich die telegrafische Adresse der Organisation, wurde jedoch 1956 als offizielle Bezeichnung übernommen. Interpol stellt nach den Vereinten Nationen und der FIFA mit gegenwärtig 186 Mitgliedsstaaten die drittgrößte internationale Organisation dar.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]L'Interpol (o International Criminal Police Organization, Organizzazione Internazionale di Polizia Criminale) è stata creata nel 1923 per assistere nella cooperazione internazionale tra polizie criminali. Interpol, che una volta era semplicemente l'indirizzo telegrafico dell'organizzazione, è stato ufficialmente incorporato nel nome dell'organizzazione nel 1956, mentre precedentemente era conosciuta come International Criminal Police Commission (Commissione Internazionale di Polizia Criminale). L'Interpol è la terza organizzazione più grande al mondo, dopo le Nazioni Unite e la FIFA; attualmente consta di 186 paesi membri.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]La Interpol ("International Criminal Police Organization" u "Organización Internacional de Policía Criminal" en castellano) fue fundada en 1923 para mejorar la cooperación internacional de la policía criminal. El nombre "Interpol", que entonces solo era la dirección de telégrafo de la organización, fue adoptado en 1956 como nuevo nombre oficial de la organización, que dejó de llamarse Comisión Internacional de Policía Criminal. Interpol es la tercera organización internacional más grande del mundo, después de las Naciones Unidas y la FIFA, y cuenta con 186 países miembro.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Great Sphinx of Giza, commonly referred to as the Sphinx, is a limestone statue of a reclining or couchant sphinx (a mythical creature with a lion's body and a human head) that stands on the Giza Plateau on the west bank of the Nile in Giza, Egypt.[PARAGRAPH:1]It is the largest monolith statue in the world, standing 73.5 metres (241 ft) long, 19.3 metres (63 ft) wide, and 20.22 m (66.34 ft) high. It is the oldest known monumental sculpture, and is commonly believed to have been built by ancient Egyptians of the Old Kingdom during the reign of the pharaoh Khafra (c. 2558–2532 BC).

[TAB]A palace is the home of a head of state or other high-ranking public figure. Many palaces are now put to other uses such as parliaments or museums. Heads of State, especially monarchs, usually spend some weeks each year in other palaces that are not their primary residence. Such palaces are often called Winter Palaces or Summer Palaces, depending on the season they are used. A few examples are the Russian Winter Palace in St. Petersburg, the Chinese Summer Palace in Beijing, and the Kucuksu Summer Palace in Istanbul.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Un palais est un lieu où réside un chef d'Etat ou un personnage public important. Beaucoup de palais ont aujourd'hui été reconvertis en parlements ou en musées. Les chefs d'Etat, et principalement les monarques, passent généralement quelques semaines par an dans des palais secondaires. Ces palais sont souvent appelés palais d'hiver ou palais d'été, suivant la saison à laquelle ils sont occupés. On peut citer, par exemple, le palais d'hiver de Saint-Pétersbourg en Russie, le palais d'été de Beijing en Chine, et le palais d'été de Küçüksu à Istanbul.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine Residenz ist der Wohnsitz eines Staatsoberhaupts oder einer anderen hochrangigen Person des öffentlichen Lebens. Viele Residenzen dienen heute als Parlamentssitze oder Museen. Staatsoberhäupter, insbesondere Monarchen, leben in der Regel einige Wochen im Jahr nicht in ihrem Hauptwohnsitz, sondern (je nach Jahreszeit) in ihren so genannten Winter- oder Sommerresidenzen. Beispiele hierfür sind der russische Winterpalast in St. Petersburg, der chinesische Sommerpalast in Peking und der Kücüksu-Sommerpalast in Istanbul.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Un palazzo è la casa di un capo di stato o di un'altra importante figura pubblica. Molti palazzi ora sono adibiti a usi diversi, come parlamenti o musei. I capi di stato, specialmente i monarchi, passano qualche settimana ogni anno in palazzi che non sono la loro residenza primaria. Solitamente sono chiamati palazzo d'inverno o d'estate, a seconda della stagione in cui vengono usati. Un esempio sono il Palazzo d'Inverno a San Pietroburgo, il Palazzo d'Estate a Pechino e il Palazzo d'Estate Kucuksu a Istanbul.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Un palacio es el hogar del jefe de estado o de otro personaje público de alto rango. Hoy en día, muchos palacios se usan para cosas diferentes, por ejemplo, como sedes del Parlamento o museos. Los cabezas de estado, especialmente los monarcas, solían pasar algunas semanas del año fuera de su residencia habitual, en otros palacios. Dichos edificios solían recibir el nombre de palacios de invierno o de verano, en función de la estación en la que fueran utilizados. Algunos ejemplos son el Palacio de Invierno ruso de San Petersburgo, el Palacio de Verano chino de Pekín, y el Palacio de Kucuksu, de verano, en Estambul.

TEXT.English: The Tamil Sangams were assemblies of Tamil scholars and poets that, according to traditional Tamil accounts, occurred in the remote past. Some scholars believe that these assemblies were originally known as kootal or gathering. Three assemblies are described. The legend has it that the first two of which were held in cities since "taken by the sea", and the third of which was held during the 5th century BC in the present-day city of Madurai.

[TAB]The Terracotta Army is a collection of terracotta sculptures depicting the armies of Qin Shi Huang, the first Emperor of China. It is a form of funerary art buried with the emperor in 210-209 BC and whose purpose was to help guard his empire in his afterlife.[NEWLINE][TAB]The figures, dating from 3rd century BC, were discovered in 1974 by some local farmers in Lintong District, Xi'an, Shaanxi province, near the Mausoleum of the First Qin Emperor.[NEWLINE][TAB]The figures vary in height, according to their roles, with the tallest being the generals. The figures include warriors, chariots, horses, officials, acrobats, strongmen and musicians. Current estimates are that in the three pits containing the Terracotta Army there were over 8,000 soldiers, 130 chariots with 520 horses and 150 cavalry horses, the majority of which are still buried in the pits.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Terracotta Army was discovered in the spring of 1974 to the east of Xi'an in Shaanxi Province by a group of farmers when they were digging a water well 1.5 miles (2.4 km) north of Mount Li (Lishan), a region riddled with underground springs and watercourses. For centuries, there were reports of pieces of terracotta figures and fragments of the Qin necropolis - roofing tiles, bricks, and chunks of masonry - having been occasionally dug up in the area. This most recent discovery prompted archaeologists to investigate, and they unearthed the largest pottery figurine group ever found in China. In 195 B.C., Liu Bang - the first emperor of the dynasty that followed the Qin - had ordered that 'twenty households' should move to the site of the mausoleum of the First Emperor of Qin (Shi Huangdi, "Shi Huangdi" means the first emperor) to watch over the tomb. To this day, twenty villages sit in the immediate vicinity of the mausoleum, one of them the hamlet where those who made the discovery lived.[PARAGRAPH:2]In addition to the warriors, an entire man-made necropolis for the emperor has also been found. Qin Shi Huangdi's necropolis complex was constructed as a microcosm of his imperial palace or compound. It consists of several offices, halls, stables and other structures placed around the tomb mound which is surrounded by two solidly built rammed earth walls with gateway entrances. Up to 5 meters (16 feet) of reddish, sandy soil had accumulated over the site in the centuries following its construction, but archaeologists found evidence of earlier disturbances at the site. During the digs at Mount Li, archaeologists found several graves dating from the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, where diggers had apparently struck terracotta fragments which were then discarded as worthless back into the back-filled soil.[NEWLINE][TAB]According to historian Sima Qian (145-90 BC), work on this mausoleum began in 246 BC soon after Emperor Qin ascended the throne (then aged 13), and the full construction later involved 700,000 workers. Geographer Li Daoyuan, six centuries after the death of the First Emperor, recorded in Shui Jing Zhu that Mount Li was a favoured location due to its auspicious geology: "... famed for its jade mines, its northen side was rich in gold, and its southern side rich in beautiful jade; the First Emperor, envious of its fine reputation, therefore chose to be buried there". Sima Qian, in his most famous work, Shiji, completed a century after the mausoleum completion, wrote that the First Emperor was buried with palaces, towers, officials, valuable artefacts and wonderful objects. According to this account, there were 100 rivers simulated with flowing mercury, and above them the ceiling was decorated with heavenly bodies below which were the features of the land. Some translations of this passage refer to "models" or "imitations," those words however weren't used in the original text.[PARAGRAPH:2]Recent scientific work at the site has found high levels of mercury in the soil of the tomb mound, giving some credence to Sima Qian 's account of the emperor's tomb. The tomb mound is located at the foot of Mount Li as an earthen pyramid, and the tomb of Shi Huangdi appears to be a hermetically sealed space that is as big as a football pitch and located underneath the pyramid. The tomb remains unopened, one possible reason may be concerns about the preservation of valuable artifacts once the tomb is opened. For example, the painted surface of the terracotta army began to flake and fade once they have been excavated. Later historical accounts suggested that the tomb had been looted by Xiang Yu, a contender for the throne, five years after the death of the emperor, however there are indications that the tomb may not have been plundered.[NEWLINE][TAB]Only a portion of the site is presently excavated, and photos and video recordings are prohibited in some viewing areas. Only a few foreign dignitaries, such as Queen Elizabeth II, have been permitted to walk through the pits to observe the army at close quarters.

A Ho Trai is the library of a Thai Buddhist temple.[PARAGRAPH:2]For many centuries, the sacred Tripitaka scriptures had been written on palm leaves. To preserve the scriptures against humidity and against termites, the library was often built on columns to raise the storage from the ground. Bricks were preferably used in constructions to battle termites. Sometimes the Ho trai would be built, especially for this reason, above man-made ponds.[PARAGRAPH:2]Traditionally, the Tripitaka scriptures consisted of individual palm leaves, each measuring around 50 cm in length and around 4 to 6 cm in width. They were perforated and threaded in order to combine them in stacks of 20 to 40 pages. These stacks are kept pressed between two pieces of teakwood which is then wrapped in cloth and stored in a special bookcase. These bookcases are sometimes exquisitely crafted with mother-of-pearl inlay or with gold leaf applied on black lacquer. Beautiful examples of bookcases can be seen in the Bangkok National Museum. Modern Tripitaka are now printed as books.

[TAB]The original walls of Constantinople were built in the 8th century BC when Byzantium was founded by Greek colonists from Megara. At the time the city consisted of an acropolis and little more. The colony was relatively unimportant by the Roman period, but Septimius Severus built a new set of walls during his reign, bringing more land into the city. When Constantine moved the capital of the empire to Byzantium, which he renamed Constantinople, he greatly expanded the walls of the city, incorporating even more territory.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 412 the Roman emperor Theodosius II surrounded Constantinople with a wall that stretched 6.5 kilometers between the Sea of Marmara and the Golden Horn. Although named after Theodosius, they were actually constructed under the direction of Anthemius, Praetorian prefect of the Eastern Empire.[PARAGRAPH:2]The walls were built of stone and brick in two lines of defense which adjoined a ditch 20 meters wide and 10 meters deep. The inner wall had was 5 meters thick and 12 meters high. It was strengthened with 96 unapproachable towers 18-20 meters tall. The thickness of the external wall was 2 meters, and its height was 8.5 meters. The wall contained the Belgrad, Silivrikapi, Mevlevihane, Topkapi, Edirnekapi, Egrikapi and Yedikule gates. Yedikule Gate was also known as the "Porta Aurea" or "Golden Gate", and was the most magnificent, consisting of three archways. As the state entrance into the capital, the Golden Gate was architecturally splendid, and was built of large square blocks of polished marble fitted together without cement, and flanked by two great towers of the same material. Upon the gates were placed sculpted elephants.[PARAGRAPH:2]The inner walls had massive square or hexagonal towers. The southern end of the walls, at the Sea of Marmara, was the location of the Marble Tower. There were ten gates, the four major ones being the Golden Gate at the southern end, the Selymbria Gate leading to the Forum of Constantine and Hagia Sophia, the Adrianople Gate connecting Constantinople's Mese (the main street) with the city of Adrianople and the Via Egnatia, and the Blachernae Gate in the north.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 439 the first sea walls were built. In 447 the wall was damaged by an earthquake, but was quickly restored in time to stop Attila's army. In the northwestern corner of the city, in the suburb of Blachernae, the Theodosian walls were relatively weaker, but were expanded by Leo I. The northern coast of the city, along the Golden Horn, also had a separate set of walls.[PARAGRAPH:2]These walls were almost inpenetrable, saving the city during sieges from the Bulgars, Arabs, and Rus', among others. The first attackers to break through the walls were the knights of the Fourth Crusade, who managed to scale the lower sea walls and also break the Wall of Leo in the northwestern Blachernae section of the city.[PARAGRAPH:2]The second and final time the walls were breached was during the Siege of Constantinople in 1453, by the Ottomans; however, they did not break through by force, but entered through the Kerkoporta Gate, which happened to be open, apparently accidentally but possibly through treachery. A large plaque today marks the spot where the Ottomans entered. Mehmed had the walls repaired in short order among other massive public works projects. Within a few years, due to the renewed importance of the city as the new Ottoman capital, the population started to soar again.[PARAGRAPH:2]Under the Ottomans, the Golden Gate, known to them as Yedikule ("the Seven Towers"), was used as a prison. Many parts of the walls are still standing today and are a testament to the extraordinary longevity of the empire. They have been damaged by recent earthquakes, but many sections have also been restored. The wall runs through the suburbs of modern Istanbul, with a belt of parkland flanking their course. The walls are pierced at intervals by modern roads leading westwards out of the city.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Theodosianische Mauer ist eine Anfang des 5. Jahrhunderts unter Kaiser Theodosius II. und dem Präfekten Anthemius errichtete, etwa 19-20 Kilometer lange Befestigungsanlage (Land- und Seemauern) zum Schutz von Konstantinopel, dem heutigen Istanbul.[PARAGRAPH:2]Die Theodosianische Mauer wird von einigen Historikern als eine der erfolgreichsten und bestdurchdachten Befestigungsanlagen in der Geschichte der Kriegstechnik angesehen. Viele der einschneidensten Ereignisse in der Geschichte der Stadt stehen eng mit diesem außergewöhnlichen Bauwerk in Zusammenhang. Der Bau des Wallsystems wurde notwendig, um der Bedrohung durch die Hunnen zu begegnen und der rasch expandierenden Stadt zusätzlichen Raum zu verschaffen. Trotz zunehmenden Verfalles und dem Aufkommen der Feuerwaffen, waren die Befestigungen bei entschlossener Verteidigung auch noch in der Mitte des 15. Jahrhunderts nur schwer zu überwinden. Die Komplexität der Verteidigungsanlagen trug wesentlich zum langen Bestehen des Byzantinischen Reiches bei.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Gompas are Buddhist temples (typically forming monasteries or nunneries, Sanskrit name vihara), located in Tibet, Ladakh (India), Nepal, and Bhutan. Their design and interior details vary from region to region, however, all follow a general layout of a central prayer hall containing a Buddha statue, benches for the monks or nuns to engage in prayer or meditation and attached living accomodation. The gompa may also be accompanied by any number of stupas.

[TAB]The Topkapi Palace is a palace in Istanbul, Turkey, which was the official and primary residence in the city of the Ottoman Sultans, from 1465 to 1853. The palace was a setting for state occasions and royal entertainments and is a major tourist attraction today. The name directly translates as "Cannongate Palace", from the palace being named after a nearby, now lost gate.[PARAGRAPH:2]The initial construction started in 1459, ordered by Sultan Mehmed II, the conqueror of Byzantine Constantinople. The palace is a complex made up of four main courtyards and many smaller buildings. At the height of its existence as a royal residence, the palace was home to as many as 4,000 people, formerly covering a larger area with a long shoreline. The complex has been expanded over the centuries, with many renovations such as after the 1509 earthquake and 1665 fire.[PARAGRAPH:2]Topkapi Palace gradually lost its importance at the end of the 17th century, as the Sultans preferred to spend more time in their new palaces along the Bosporus. In 1853, Sultan Abdül Mecid I decided to move the court to the newly built Dolmabahçe Palace, the first European-style palace in the city. Some functions, such as the imperial treasury, the library, mosque and mint, were retained though.[PARAGRAPH:2]After the end of the Ottoman Empire in 1921, Topkapi Palace was transformed by government decree on April 3, 1924 into a museum of the imperial era. The Topkapi Palace Museum is under the administration of the Ministry of Culture and Tourism. The palace complex has hundreds of rooms and chambers, but only the most important are accessible to the public today. The complex is guarded by officials of the ministry as well as armed guards of the Turkish military. The palace is full of examples of Ottoman architecture and also contains large collections of porcelain, robes, weapons, shields, armor, Ottoman miniatures, Islamic calligraphic manuscripts and murals, as well as a display of Ottoman treasure and jewelry.[PARAGRAPH:2]Topkapi Palace is among those monuments belonging to the "Historic Areas of Istanbul", which became a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1985, and is described in Criterion iv as "the best example(s) of ensembles of palaces of the Ottoman period."
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Topkapi-Palast (im Deutschen auch Topkapi-Serail, wörtlich "Kanonentor-Palast") in Istanbul war jahrhundertelang der Wohn- und Regierungssitz der Sultane sowie das Verwaltungszentrum des Osmanischen Reiches.[PARAGRAPH:2]Mit dem Bau wurde kurz nach der Eroberung Konstantinopels (1453) durch Sultan Mehmed II. begonnen. Zunächst ordnete er die Errichtung des Palastes auf dem heutigen Beyazitplatz (Beyazit Meydani) an, entschied sich dann aber für die heute Sarayburnu genannte Landspitze zwischen Goldenem Horn und Marmarameer. Dabei wurden Teile des byzantinischen Mangana-Palastes überbaut. Ihr heutiges Aussehen erhielt die Anlage durch umfangreiche Renovierungen und Erweiterungen bis zum Anfang des 18. Jahrhunderts. Seit Mehmed II. residierten alle osmanischen Herrscher im Topkapi-Palast, bis Sultan Abdülmecid I. im Jahre 1856 das neue Dolmabahçe Sarayi auf der anderen Seite des Goldenen Horns am Ufer des Bosporus bezog. Beide Paläste sind heute Museen.[PARAGRAPH:2]Der Palast besteht nicht aus einem einzelnen, sondern getreu der türkischen Tradition aus mehreren Gebäuden in einem großen Garten. Mit einer Fläche von über 69 Hektar und bis zu 5000 Bewohnern war der Palast eine eigene Stadt. Man nannte ihn anfangs Saray-i Cedîd-i Âmire oder Yeni Saray /,Neuer Palast', bevor sich im 18. Jahrhundert der Name Topkapi Sarayi durchsetzte, der sich von der palasteigenen Kanonengießerei ableitete.[PARAGRAPH:2]Der Palast ist in vier Höfe unterteilt, die jeweils durch eigene Tore erreicht werden. Mit seiner Lage auf einer Landspitze bietet er eine beispiellose Panoramasicht auf Istanbul, den Bosporus und das Goldene Horn.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A trading company is an association formed by investors or shareholders for the purpose of trade, exploration and colonisation. Typically, these companies were formed from the sixteenth century onwards by groups of European investors to underwrite and profit from the exploration of Africa, India, the Caribbean and North America, usually under the patronage of one state, which issued the company's charter. Notable companies include British East India Company and Dutch Verenigde Oostindische Compagnie.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Une compagnie marchande est une association formée par des investisseurs ou des actionnaires s'intéressant au commerce, à l'exploration et à la colonisation. Ces compagnies furent créées à partir du XVIe siècle, généralement par des investisseurs européens, pour financer l'exploration de l'Afrique, de l'Inde, des Caraïbes et de l'Amérique du Nord, et bien sûr en tirer profit. Elles étaient généralement sous le patronage d'un Etat, qui leur accordait une charte. Parmi les compagnies les plus connues, on peut citer la British East India Company (Compagnie anglaise des Indes orientales) et la Dutch Verenigde Oostindische Compagnie (Compagnie hollandaise des Indes orientales).
TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine Handelsgesellschaft ist eine von Investoren oder Aktionären gebildete Interessengemeinschaft zum Zwecke des Handels, der Ausbeutung und der Kolonialisierung. Derartige Gesellschaften wurden seit dem 16. Jahrhundert von europäischen Investoren gebildet, um sich den Anspruch auf die privilegierte Ausbeutung Afrikas, Indiens, Nordamerikas und des karibischen Raumes sowie die damit verbundenen Profite zu sichern, üblicherweise unter der Führung eines Staates, der den Freibrief für die Gesellschaft ausstellte. Bedeutende Gesellschaften dieser Art waren die Britische Ostindien-Kompanie und die Niederländische Ostindien-Kompanie.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Una compagnia commerciale è un'associazione formata da investitori o azionisti con lo scopo di commerciare, esplorare e colonizzare. Queste compagnie nacquero a partire dal sedicesimo secolo per volontà di investitori europei, che desideravano finanziare e approfittare dell'esplorazione di Africa, India, Caraibi e Nord America, solitamente con l'appoggio di uno stato, che emetteva l'atto costitutivo della società. Tra le più famose ci sono la Compagnia delle Indie Orientali Britannica e la Compagnia Olandese delle Indie Orientali.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Una compañía de las Indias es una asociación de inversores o accionistas cuyos fines son promocionar el comercio, la exploración y la colonización. Estas compañías se formaron a partir del siglo XVI por grupos de inversores europeos que querían financiar la exploración de África, la India, el Caribe y el norte de América, normalmente bajo la tutela de un estado, que emitía la carta real o los estatutos de la compañía. Algunas de las más notables fueron la británica Compañía de las Indias Orientales y la Verenigde Oostindische Compagnie holandesa.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Trafalgar Square is a public space and tourist attraction in central London, England, United Kingdom built around the area formerly known as Charing Cross. It is in the borough of the City of Westminster. At its centre is Nelson's Column, which is guarded by four lion statues at its base. There are a number of statues and sculptures in the square, with one plinth displaying changing pieces of contemporary art. The square is also used for political demonstrations and community gatherings, such as the celebration of New Year's Eve.[PARAGRAPH:1]The name commemorates the Battle of Trafalgar (1805), a British naval victory of the Napoleonic Wars over France. The original name was to have been "King William the Fourth's Square", but George Ledwell Taylor suggested the name "Trafalgar Square".[PARAGRAPH:1]In the 1820s, George IV engaged the architect John Nash to redevelop the area. Nash cleared the square as part of his Charing Cross Improvement Scheme. The present architecture of the square is due to Sir Charles Barry and was completed in 1845.[PARAGRAPH:1]Trafalgar Square is owned by the Queen in Right of the Crown, and managed by the Greater London Authority, while Westminster City Council owns the roads around the square, including the pedestrianised area of the North Terrace.

[TAB]A stock exchange, share market or bourse is a corporation or mutual organization which provides facilities for stock brokers and traders, to trade company stocks and other securities. Stock exchanges also provide facilities for the issue and redemption of securities, as well as, other financial instruments and capital events including the payment of income and dividends. The most famous one is New York Stock Exchange, based in Wall Street.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Une Bourse, ou un marché financier, est une organisation qui permet aux courtiers et aux opérateurs de négocier des actions et d'autres titres. Les Bourses fournissent aussi l'infrastructure pour l'émission et le remboursement de titres ainsi que divers outils financiers, et elles permettent des opérations de capitaux comme le paiement de revenus et de dividendes. La Bourse la plus célèbre est celle de New York, située sur Wall Street.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine Börse ist ein organisierter Markt für Geschäfte mit Aktien, Anleihen, Devisen, oder bestimmten Waren, die von so genannten Maklern oder Brokern (Wertpapierhändlern) getätigt werden. Ebenso werden hier Wertpapiere und andere finanzielle Instrumente und Kapitalgeschäfte abgewickelt, einschließlich der Zahlung von Gewinnen und Dividenden. Die berühmteste Börse ist die New York Stock Exchange in der Wall Street.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Una borsa è una corporazione o organizzazione che fornisce la possibilità ad agenti e scambisti di scambiare azioni e altre security delle varie compagnie. Le borse servono anche per l'emissione e il riscatto delle security, così come di altri strumenti finanziari ed eventi capitali, incluso il pagamento di entrate e dividendi. La più famosa al mondo è la borsa di New York, che si trova a Wall Street.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]La bolsa o mercado de valores es una corporación u organización que proporciona instalaciones a los "corredores" y comerciantes para intercambiar acciones de empresas y otros títulos. Las bolsas también brindan facilidades para librar, expedir o reembolsar títulos, así como instrumentos financieros apropiados para el pago de rentas y dividendos. La más famosa es la que se encuentra en la calle Wall Street de Nueva York.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Bastille was a prison in Paris, known formally as Bastille Saint-Antoine, best known today because of the storming of the Bastille on July 14, 1789, which along with the Tennis Court Oath is considered the beginning of the French Revolution. Bastille is a French word meaning "castle" or "stronghold"; used as a single word ("la Bastide" in French), it refers to the prison. Built from 1370 to 1383 as part of the defences of Paris, the structure was later converted into a prison.
TEXT.French: [TAB]La Bastille, ou plus précisément la Bastille Saint-Antoine, était une prison de Paris. Elle devint célèbre avec la prise de la Bastille le 14 juillet 1789 qui marqua, avec le serment du jeu de paume, le début de la Révolution française. Dérivé de "bastide", le mot "bastille" signifie "château" ou "forteresse". Utilisé comme nom propre, il désigne la prison. Commencé en 1370 et achevé en 1383, l'ouvrage devait servir à la défense de Paris. Il fut par la suite transformé en prison.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die Bastille war das Staatgefängnis in Paris, früher offiziell als "Bastille Saint-Antoine" bezeichnet, das heute vor allem durch den Sturm auf die Bastille am 14. Juli 1789 berühmt ist, der zusammen mit dem "Ballhausschwur" als Beginn der französischen Revolution erachtet wird. Das französische Wort "Bastille" bedeutet übersetzt etwa "kleine Bastion" oder "kleine Burg". Das Gebäude wurde von 1370 bis 1383 als Teil der Verteidigungsanlagen von Paris erbaut und später als Kerkeranlage genutzt, weshalb der Begriff "Bastille" heute gleichbedeutend mit Gefängnis verwendet wird.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]La Bastiglia era una prigione di Parigi, il cui nome completo francese è Bastille Saint-Antoine, conosciuta al giorno d'oggi per l'assalto che subì il 14 luglio 1789 e che, assieme al Giuramento della Sala della Pallacorda, è considerato l'inizio della rivoluzione francese. Bastille è una parola francese che significa "castello" o "fortezza"; usata da sola ("la Bastide" in francese) si riferisce a una prigione. Costruita nel periodo che va dal 1370 al 1383 come parte delle difese di Parigi, venne più tardi convertita in una prigione.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]La Bastilla fue una prisión parisina, conocida antiguamente como "Bastide Saint-Antoine". Hoy es más conocida por la célebre toma de la Bastilla que se produjo el 14 de julio de 1789, que, junto con el Juramento del Juego de la Pelota, se considera el comienzo de la Revolución Francesa. "Bastide" es una palabra francesa que significa "castillo" o "fortaleza", mientras que "Bastille", el nombre con el que ha pasado a la historia, significa "prisión". Fue construida entre 1370 y 1383 como parte del complejo defensivo de París, aunque más tarde se convirtió en una prisión.

TEXT.English: [TAB]The Palace of Westminster is the meeting place of the House of Commons and the House of Lords, the two houses of the Parliament of the United Kingdom. Commonly known as the Houses of Parliament after its tenants, the Palace lies on the Middlesex bank of the River Thames in the City of Westminster, in central London. Its name, which derives from the neighbouring Westminster Abbey, may refer to either of two structures: the Old Palace, a medieval building complex that was destroyed by fire in 1834, and its replacement New Palace that stands today.
