Although scientists have not yet tested the effects of long-term freezing on human beings, they are completely confident that there will not be any problems with the Stasis Chamber on the Space Ship.[PARAGRAPH:1]Completely confident.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Le voyage devant durer des décennies, voire des siècles, l'une des considérations les plus importantes des ingénieurs tenait au vieillissement de l'équipage. Les récentes avancées réalisées dans le domaine de la cryogénie et des thérapies chimiques ont permis aux ingénieurs de ralentir chimiquement le processus métabolique et même d'aboutir pratiquement à un arrêt virtuel, ce qui permet ensuite aux ingénieurs de congeler les corps sans les endommager. Des détecteurs assurent un environnement sans oxygène afin de garantir le fait que les colons puissent rester en bon état le plus longtemps possible. Un système spécial de réchauffement utilisant un large spectre de radiation électromagnétique pourra être utilisé pour réchauffer les corps rapidement et en toute sécurité. [PARAGRAPH:1]La radiation a aussi pour effet de décomposer les agents chimiques qui ralentissent le métabolisme des colons, leur permettant d'être décongelés en une fraction de seconde et de reprendre parfaitement connaissance en un peu plus d'une minute. Cet aspect est essentiel à la survie de l'équipage dans le cas où l'ordinateur est incapable de déterminer ce qui se passe et qu'un pilote ou navigateur doit être réveillé pour apprécier un danger, ou dans la situation où un technicien doit être réveillé pour effectuer des réparations. [PARAGRAPH:1]Ce système a été testé avec succès sur des cochons et des singes, ces expériences ayant montré que ces animaux en profond sommeil cryogénique pouvaient se réveiller trois ans plus tard, ne subissant aucun effet secondaire visible. Un couple de volontaires militaires a également été congelé pour tester le système, mais seulement pendant quelques semaines. Si les scientifiques n'ont pas encore testé les effets à long terme de la congélation sur des êtres humains, ils sont absolument certains qu'il n'y aura aucun problème avec le module de stase du vaisseau spatial.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Angesichts einer Reise, die voraussichtlich Jahrzehnte, wenn nicht gar Jahrhunderte dauern sollte, war eines der größten Probleme der Ingenieure der Alterungsprozess der Besatzung. Neue Erkenntnisse auf dem Gebiet der Tieftemperaturtechnik und innovative chemische Therapien ermöglichten es den Wissenschaftlern, den Stoffwechsel praktisch zum Erliegen zu bringen, wodurch ein menschlicher Körper gefahrlos tiefgefroren werden kann. Die sauerstofflose Umgebungsatmosphäre in den Stasekammern wird mit Hilfe empfindlicher Sensoren reguliert, die größtmögliche Sicherheit für die "eingefrorenen" Kolonisten gewährleisten. Zur schnellen und sicheren Wiederherstellung der normalen Körpertemperatur dient ein spezielles Auftausystem, bei dem ein Breitbandspektrum elektromagnetischer Strahlung zum Einsatz kommt. [PARAGRAPH:1]Die Strahlung bewirkt, dass die chemischen Wirkstoffe, die den Stoffwechsel der Kolonisten verlangsamen, aufgespaltet werden. Dank dieses Verfahrens können die Menschen innerhalb von Sekunden aufgetaut werden und sind nach einem Zeitraum von etwas über einer Minute wieder vollkommen wohlauf. Dieser Aspekt der Stasetechnologie ist besonders wichtig für das Überleben des Raumfahrzeugs, z.B. wenn eine Situation eintritt, in der der Computer das geeignete Vorgehen nicht eigenständig einschätzen kann, so dass ein Pilot oder Navigator geweckt werden muss, um sich der Sache anzunehmen. Auch kann es im Laufe der Reise notwendig werden, einen Techniker zu wecken, um Reparaturen durchzuführen. [PARAGRAPH:1]Das Stasesystem wurde sehr erfolgreich an Schweinen und Affen getestet: Es hat sich gezeigt, dass die Tiere nach drei Jahren im Tiefkühlschlaf ohne sichtbare Nebeneffekte wieder geweckt werden konnten. Außerdem wurden auch einige freiwillige Militärbedienstete eingefroren, allerdings nur für ein paar Wochen. Obwohl man die Auswirkungen der Langzeitgefrierung auf den Menschen bisher noch nicht restlos erforschen konnte, sind die verantwortlichen Wissenschaftler absolut zuversichtlich, dass es keinerlei Probleme mit den Stasekammern auf dem Raumschiff geben wird [PARAGRAPH:1]- gar keine.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]In un viaggio che, secondo le previsioni, dovrebbe durare decenni, se non secoli, una delle considerazioni più importanti degli ingegneri è stata l'invecchiamento dell'equipaggio. Le recenti scoperte nella criogenia e nella chemioterapia hanno consentito agli scienziati di rallentare chimicamente il processo metabolico, fino ad arrestarlo, cosa che consente di congelare il corpo senza danneggiarlo. I sensori regolano l'ambiente senza ossigeno, per assicurare che i coloni siano mantenuti al sicuro il più possibile, mentre un sistema speciale di riscaldamento che si avvale di radiazioni elettromagnetiche ad ampio spettro è usato per ripristinare velocemente e senza pericolo il calore del corpo.[PARAGRAPH:1]La radiazione ha anche l'effetto di eliminare gli agenti chimici che rallentano il metabolismo dei coloni, rendendo possibile un loro riscaldamento nel giro di qualche secondo e un loro completo risveglio in poco più di un minuto. Si tratta di un processo fondamentale per la sopravvivenza dell'equipaggio, in una situazione in cui il computer non è in grado di determinare una serie di azioni e si rende necessario un pilota o un navigatore per valutare il pericolo, oppure in una situazione in cui serve un tecnico per effettuare delle riparazioni.[PARAGRAPH:1]Questo sistema è stato usato in modo molto efficace nei test sui maiali e sulle scimmie e ha dimostrato che questi animali, avvolti in un profondo sonno criogenico, sono stati scongelati dopo tre anni senza nessun effetto collaterale visibile. Anche un paio di volontari militari sono stati congelati per provare il sistema, ma solo per qualche settimana. Malgrado gli scienziati non abbiano ancora verificato gli effetti del congelamento a lungo termine sugli esseri umani, sono assolutamente fiduciosi sul fatto che non sorgeranno problemi con la camera di stasi sull'astronave.[PARAGRAPH:1]Assolutamente fiduciosi.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Con un viaje con una duración prevista de décadas, si no siglos, una de las consideraciones más importantes de los diseñadores fue el envejecimiento de la tripulación. Ciertos avances recientes en los campos de la criogenia y la terapia química permitieron ralentizar químicamente el proceso metabólico hasta casi detenerlo, lo que posibilitó que los científicos pudieran ultracongelar los cuerpos sin dañarlos. Hay sensores que se encargan de regular el ambiente al vacío para garantizar que los colonos estén tan seguros como sea posible, y un sistema de calefacción que utiliza radiación electromagnética de amplio espectro para devolver el calor al cuerpo de manera rápida y segura.[PARAGRAPH:1]La radiación también se encarga de descomponer los agentes químicos que ralentizan el metabolismo de los colonos, permitiendo que sean descongelados en cuestión de segundos y estén plenamente conscientes en menos de un minuto. Esto es esencial para la supervivencia de la nave en una situación en la que el ordenador no pueda determinar las acciones a emprender y haya que despertar al piloto o navegante para evaluar el peligro, o a un ingeniero para llevar a cabo las reparaciones.[PARAGRAPH:1]Este sistema ha sido probado con gran efectividad en cerdos y monos, y se ha demostrado que esos animales pueden salir de un profundo sueño criogénico sin ningún efecto secundario constatable. También se ha congelado a un par de voluntarios del ejército para probar el sistema, pero solo durante unas semanas. Aunque los científicos todavía no han puesto a prueba los efectos de la congelación a largo plazo, están completamente seguros de que no puede haber ningún problema con la cámara criogénica de la nave.[PARAGRAPH:1]Completamente seguros.

TEXT.English: [BOLD]Strategy:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1][COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Thrusters[COLOR_REVERT] are required to launch your spaceship. They also increase the speed of the spaceship.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]The massive Thrusters are, much like the Engine, designed to function in a myriad of ways. Designed in stages like the Engines, the Thrusters channel the exhaust used to propel the Space Ship through all of its phases of travel. In the initial phase, the external booster rockets channel their fuel through the Thrusters array until they run out of fuel, at which point they are jettisoned. After that, the powerful electromagnets built into the Thrusters help accelerate the charged particles of the ion drive to near the speed of light, providing a great deal of thrust for the Space Ship.[PARAGRAPH:1]Finally, in the last stages of travel, the Thrusters are responsible for maneuvering the Space Ship into the planet's gravity well and providing a counter thrust to slow the vessel to a manageable velocity to settle into a geo-synchronous orbit. In order to fulfill all of these functions, the Thrusters array had to be capable of the ultra-sensitive duty of accelerating high energy ions as well as be able to handle the hundreds of thousands of pounds of thrust produced by the solid fuel boosters.[PARAGRAPH:1]The engineers who designed the Thrusters were able to fulfill both of these functions as well as making them articulated to allow for maneuverability that is remarkable considering the mass and projected velocities of the craft.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Les gigantesques propulseurs, comme le moteur, comportent plusieurs étages et sont conçus de façon à ce qu'ils puissent fonctionner de diverses manières. Ils canalisent les gaz d'échappement nécessaires à la propulsion du vaisseau spatial durant toutes les phases de son voyage. Au départ, les fusées d'appoint externes acheminent leur combustible dans les divers propulseurs jusqu'à ce qu'elles n'en aient plus et qu'elles soient éjectées. Ensuite, les puissants électro-aimants construits dans les propulseurs contribuent à accélérer les particules chargées du moteur à ions pour approcher de la vitesse de la lumière et offrir ainsi une très forte poussée au vaisseau spatial.[PARAGRAPH:1]Enfin, au cours des dernières étapes du voyage, les propulseurs sont chargés d'amener le vaisseau spatial dans le puits de gravité de la planète et de fournir une contre-poussée pour ralentir le vaisseau à une vitesse maîtrisable afin de se mettre dans une orbite synchronisée avec celle de la Terre. Pour assumer toutes ces fonctions, les divers propulseurs devaient être capable de mener à bien la tâche ultra-sensible d'accélérer les ions à forte énergie et de faire face à la poussée de plusieurs centaines de milliers de kilogrammes produite par les fusées d'appoint à carburant solide.[PARAGRAPH:1]Les ingénieurs ayant conçu les propulseurs ont réussi à leur faire remplir ces deux fonctions et à leur donner une structure articulée afin d'améliorer leur manoeuvrabilité, qui est remarquable compte tenu de la masse et des vitesses prévues pour ce vaisseau spatial.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Wie der Antrieb arbeiten auch die massiven Triebwerke auf vielschichtige Art und Weise. Entsprechend der jeweiligen Flugphase kanalisieren sie stufenweise den für die Triebkraft eines Raumschiffs erforderlichen Auslass. Während der Initialphase leiten die externen Antriebsraketen ihren Treibstoff durch die Triebwerksanordnung, bis nichts mehr übrig ist. Danach werden sie abgeworfen. Als Nächstes beschleunigen die starken Elektromagneten, die in die Triebwerke integriert sind, die geladenen Partikel des Ionenantriebs auf nahezu Lichtgeschwindigkeit und bewirken dadurch eine enorme Schubleistung zum Antrieb des Raumschiffs. [PARAGRAPH:1]In den letzten Reisephasen zeichnen die Triebwerke schließlich für die Manövrierung des Raumschiffs in das Gravitationsfeld des Planeten verantwortlich, indem ein Gegenschub erzeugt wird, der das Schiff auf eine akzeptable Geschwindigkeit drosselt, um in einem geosynchronen Orbit stoppen zu können. Zur Bewerkstelligung all dieser Aufgaben muss die Triebwerksanordnung sowohl bei der Beschleunigung der Hochenergie-Ionen als auch bei der Handhabung von mehreren hunderttausend Pfund Schubkraft, die von den Feststoffraketen erzeugt werden, ultrasensitive Arbeit leisten. [PARAGRAPH:1]Die Ingenieure, die diese Triebwerke konstruierten, schafften es, diese beiden Bedingungen zu erfüllen und die Funktionalität tatsächlich so umzusetzen, dass sie angesichts der Masse und der kalkulierten Geschwindigkeiten des Raumfahrzeugs eine bemerkenswerte Manövrierfähigkeit zulassen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB] I propulsori, come il motore, sono progettati per funzionare in numerosi modi e sono strutturati in più stadi. La loro funzione è convogliare la materia di scarico che muove l'astronave durante tutte le fasi del suo viaggio. In quella iniziale, i razzi di manovra esterni convogliano verso la batteria di propulsori il carburante fino all'esaurimento, dopodiché vengono espulsi. In seguito, i potenti elettromagneti installati nei propulsori aiutano ad accelerare le particelle cariche del motore ionico fin quasi alla velocità della luce, garantendo una potente spinta all'astronave. [PARAGRAPH:1]Infine, nelle ultime fasi del viaggio, i propulsori sono responsabili della manovra dell'astronave nel campo gravitazionale del pianeta, fornendo una contro-spinta per rallentare il vascello e portarlo a una velocità gestibile, cosicché entri nell'orbita geosincrona. Per svolgere tutte queste funzioni, il vettore dei propulsori deve essere in grado di lavorare ad altissima precisione durante l'accelerazione degli ioni ad alta energia, come pure di gestire le centinaia di migliaia di chili di spinta prodotte dai razzi a carburante solido. [PARAGRAPH:1] Gli ingegneri che hanno progettato i propulsori sono stati capaci di realizzare entrambe le funzioni, come pure di renderle articolate, in modo da garantire quella manovrabilità, sorprendente considerando la massa e la velocità della nave.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Los enormes propulsores están pensados, al igual que los motores, para funcionar de muchas maneras. Diseñados por fases, como los motores, los propulsores canalizan los gases de la combustión para impulsar a la nave espacial en todas las fases de su viaje. En la fase inicial, los cohetes propulsores externos canalizan su combustible a través del conjunto de propulsores hasta que se agota, momento en el que se desechan. A continuación, los poderosos electroimanes instalados en los propulsores ayudan a acelerar las partículas del motor de iones para acercarse a la velocidad de la luz, proporcionándole un gran empuje a la nave espacial.[PARAGRAPH:1]Finalmente, en las últimas etapas del viaje, los propulsores son los encargados de maniobrar la nave hasta la órbita del planeta y proporcionar el suficiente impulso contrario para frenar la nave hasta una velocidad que permita colocarla en una órbita geosíncrona. A fin de poder cumplir todas estas funciones, los conjuntos de propulsores tenían que estar capacitados para llevar a cabo la delicadísima función de acelerar los iones a altas energías, así como poder controlar el empuje de muchas toneladas producido por los impulsores.[PARAGRAPH:1]Los ingenieros que diseñaron los propulsores pudieron satisfacer ambas funciones y la de articularlos, para así proporcionar una maniobrabilidad excepcional, teniendo en cuenta la masa y las velocidades para las que el vehículo fue proyectado.

TEXT.English: [BOLD]Strategy:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]The [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Internet[COLOR_REVERT] grants all technologies that are already discovered by 2 known civilizations.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]Background:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:1]The Internet is a computer network linked by hard wire, telephony and satellite. These computers share the same language, allowing for the fast transfer of information. Anyone with a computer and a modem (or other hookup) can utilize the Internet to gather information, to broadcast news and opinions, or to shoot at other like-minded folks in virtual reality galleries. In its few years of existence the Internet has dramatically changed the way that information is gathered and transmitted, and the network's full potential cannot be guessed. [PARAGRAPH:1]The Internet was first conceived of in the early 1960s. At that time the discussion was purely theoretical, as the computers, the connections, and the common language did not yet exist. Given that it was the height of the Cold War, neither did the necessary international cooperation. But the idea had many supporters, especially in universities and research labs around the US, and by 1969 four computers located around the country were in communication with each other through ARPA-Net. [PARAGRAPH:1]By the mid-1980s, the core of the network was in place, the communications protocols had been determined, and the Internet was live. By the early 1990s the first Internet language (http) was written and the first browser was published. The World Wide Web was born. [PARAGRAPH:1]The Internet stands today as one of the few great projects constructed largely by individuals rather than by an organization such as a corporation, religion, or government. Various portions of the network were indeed created and funded by the US Department of Defense - but much of it came together organically, built in bits and pieces by professors, scientists and engineers, perhaps less for personal gain than because they thought the "information society" was an idea worth pursuing.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Internet est un réseau informatique fonctionnant par l'interconnexion de câbles, de la téléphonie et de satellites. Ces ordinateurs partagent un même langage, ce qui permet un transfert rapide des informations. Toute personne disposant d'un ordinateur et d'un modem (ou de toute autre borne de connexion) peut utiliser Internet pour recueillir des renseignements, diffuser des informations ou son opinion ou affronter des personnes partageant cette même intention dans des galeries virtuelles. En quelques années d'existence, Internet a considérablement modifié la façon dont les informations sont recueillies et transmises mais l'on ne mesure pas encore tout le potentiel de ce réseau. [PARAGRAPH:1]Internet est né au début des années 1960. A cette époque, la discussion était purement théorique car les ordinateurs, les connexions et le langage commun n'existaient pas encore. En plein coeur de la guerre froide, aucun pays n'avait développé la coopération internationale nécessaire. L'idée était toutefois soutenue par de nombreuses personnes, notamment dans les universités et les laboratoires de recherche des Etats-Unis et en 1969, quatre ordinateurs dispersés dans le pays pouvaient communiquer entre eux grâce au réseau Arpanet. [PARAGRAPH:1]Au milieu des années 1980, le coeur du réseau était en place, les protocoles de communication étaient déterminés : Internet vivait. Au début des années 1990, le premier langage Internet (http) était écrit et le premier navigateur faisait son apparition. Le World Wide Web était né. [PARAGRAPH:1]Internet est considéré aujourd'hui comme l'un des rares grands projets développés essentiellement par des personnes individuelles, et non par des organisations telles que des entreprises, des associations religieuses ou des gouvernements. Divers aspects de ce réseau ont certes été créés et financés par le ministère américain de la défense mais il a essentiellement été construit de façon organique, les multiples pièces et composants étant mis au point par les professeurs, les scientifiques et les ingénieurs, peut-être moins pour leur profit personnel que parce qu'ils pensaient que la "société de l'information" était une idée qui méritait d'être développée.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Das Internet ist ein durch Kabel, Telefone und Satelliten verbundenes Computernetzwerk. Dank der gemeinsamen Sprache aller Computer können Informationen über das Internet sehr schnell übertragen werden. Jeder Benutzer, der über die entsprechende Hardware (Computer, Modem, DSL-Anschluss usw.) verfügt, kann auf das Internet zugreifen, um Informationen zu recherchieren, Nachrichten zu verbreiten oder sich in so genannten Virtual Realities mit anderen Benutzern zu treffen. Das Internet hat die Aufbereitung und Verbreitung von Informationen in wenigen Jahren revolutioniert, doch das volle Potenzial des Netzwerks ist noch längst nicht ausgeschöpft. [PARAGRAPH:1]Die Idee des Internets entstand Mitte der 60er Jahre des 20. Jahrhunderts, obwohl es damals weder vernetzte Computer, noch eine gemeinsame Computersprache gab. Außerdem war eine internationale Zusammenarbeit auf dem Höhepunkt des Kalten Krieges undenkbar. Trotzdem fand die Idee zahlreiche Befürworter in den Universitäten und Forschungszentren der USA. 1969 waren vier (!) Computer über das "ARPA-Net" miteinander verbunden. [PARAGRAPH:1]Mitte der 80er Jahre wurden der Kern des Netzwerks und die Kommunikationsprotokolle fertig gestellt ... das Internet war geboren. Als Anfang der 90er Jahre schließlich die erste Internetsprache (http) und der erste Browser veröffentlicht wurden, begann der Siegeszug des World Wide Web. [PARAGRAPH:1]Heute ist das Internet eines der wenigen Großprojekte, das von Einzelpersonen realisiert wurde. Verschiedene Komponenten des Netzwerks gehen auf das Pentagon zurück und wurden von Professoren, Wissenschaftlern und Ingenieuren, die von der Idee einer "Informationsgesellschaft" überzeugt waren und sind, in das natürlich gewachsene Gesamtsystem integriert.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Internet è un sistema di reti che collega computer, telefonia e satelliti. Questi computer parlano lo stesso linguaggio per comunicare, consentendo una rapida diffusione delle informazioni. Chiunque in possesso di un computer e un modem (o un altro sistema di connessione), può utilizzare Internet per ricercare informazioni, pubblicare notizie e opinioni o più semplicemente giocare con altre persone in una sorta di realtà virtuale. Negli ultimi anni, la diffusione di Internet ha cambiato drasticamente il modo nel quale cercare e diffondere informazioni: il potenziale della rete è inimmaginabile. [PARAGRAPH:1]Internet è stata concepita nei primi anni '60, in un periodo in cui una discussione del genere era puramente teorica, poiché i computer non sapevano ancora comunicare tra loro; inoltre era il culmine della Guerra Fredda e nessuno si prodigò in necessaria cooperazione internazionale. Ma l'idea aveva molti sostenitori, specialmente nelle università e nei laboratori di ricerca disseminati negli Stati Uniti; nel 1969, quattro computer dislocati in altrettante zone della nazione entrarono in comunicazione tra loro mediante la rete ARPA-Net. [PARAGRAPH:1]Verso la metà degli anni '80, il cuore della rete pulsava, i protocolli di comunicazione vennero determinati: era nato il World Wide Web. Nel 1990 venne scritto il primo linguaggio per Internet (http) e pubblicato il primo browser. [PARAGRAPH:1] Internet rappresenta uno dei pochi grandi progetti realizzati principalmente da individui piuttosto che da corporazioni o associazioni religiose e governative. Alcune parti della rete vennero create e fondate dal Dipartimento della Difesa degli Stati Uniti d'America, ma il resto arrivò organicamente, pezzo per pezzo, grazie al lavoro di professori, scienziati e ingegneri che pensarono che la "società dell'informazione" fosse un obiettivo per cui valesse la pena lavorare, anche senza fini personali.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Internet es una red de ordenadores unidos por cable, telefonía y satélite, que comparten un mismo lenguaje, lo que permite una rápida transferencia de información. Cualquiera que tenga un ordenador y un módem (u otro medio de conexión) puede utilizar Internet para recabar información, enviar noticias y opiniones o buscar gente de mentalidad afín en galerías de realidad virtual. En sus pocos años de existencia, Internet ha cambiado drásticamente las técnicas de recopilación de información, y el potencial de la red no se conoce todavía. [PARAGRAPH:1]Internet se concibió por primera vez en la década de los 60. Por aquel entonces el debate era puramente teórico, puesto que los ordenadores, las conexiones y el lenguaje común no existían. Si tenemos en cuenta que era el momento álgido de la Guerra Fría, tampoco existía el necesario clima de cooperación internacional. Pero la idea tenía muchos partidarios, especialmente en las universidades y laboratorios de EE. UU., y en 1969, cuatro ordenadores situados en puntos diferentes del país pudieron comunicarse por medio de ARPA-Net. [PARAGRAPH:1]Hacia mediados de 1980, el núcleo de la red estaba en funcionamiento, se habían establecido los protocolos de comunicación e Internet iniciaba su andadura. A principios de los 90, se creó el primer lenguaje de Internet (http) y se publicó el primer navegador. Había nacido la World Wide Web. [PARAGRAPH:1]Hoy en día, Internet es uno de los escasos ejemplos existentes de un proyecto importante construido en gran medida por individuos y no por organizaciones como grandes empresas, religiones o gobiernos. Es cierto que diversas partes de la red fueron creadas y financiadas por el Departamento de Defensa de EE. UU., pero en su conjunto nació de forma orgánica, construida pieza a pieza por profesores, científicos e ingenieros, no tanto por razones de interés personal como por amor a la idea de una "sociedad de la información".

TEXT.English: [TAB]Absolute monarchy (or simply absolutism) is a monarchical form of government where the monarch has the power to rule his or her land or country and its citizens freely, with no laws or legally-organized direct opposition in force. Although some religious authority may be able to discourage the monarch from some acts and the sovereign is expected to act according to custom, in an absolute monarchy there is no constitution or body of law above what is decreed by the sovereign (king or queen). As a theory of civics, absolute monarchy puts total trust in well-bred and well-trained monarchs raised for the role from birth.[PARAGRAPH:2]The theory of absolute monarchy developed in the late Middle Ages from feudalism, during which a monarch was still very much the "first among equals" (primes inter pares) among the nobility. With the creation of centralized administrations and standing armies backed by expensive artillery, the power of the monarch gradually increased relative to that of the nobles (whose military power had declined with the effectiveness of heavy cavalry), and from this was created the theory of absolute monarchy.[PARAGRAPH:2]In theory, an absolute monarch has total power over his or her people and land, including the aristocracy and sometimes the clergy (see caesaropapism). In practice, absolute monarchs have often found their power limited - generally by one or other of those groups.[PARAGRAPH:2]Some monarchies (for example the German Empire, 1871-1918) have powerless or symbolic parliaments and other governmental bodies that the monarch can alter or dissolve at will. Despite effectively being absolute monarchies, they are technically constitutional monarchies due to the existence of a constitution and national canon of law.[PARAGRAPH:2]The popularity of the notion of absolute monarchy declined substantially after the French Revolution and American Revolution, which promoted theories of government based on popular sovereignty. Among the few states that retain a rather absolute monarchy are Bhutan, Brunei, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Swaziland, and the Vatican City (the papal city-state, a theocractic elective monarchy).

[TAB]Agrarianism has two common meanings. The first meaning refers to a social philosophy or political philosophy which values rural society as superior to urban society, the independent farmer as superior to the paid worker, and sees farming as a way of life that can shape the ideal social values. It stresses the superiority of a simpler rural life as opposed to the complexity of city life, with its banks and factories. The American Thomas Jefferson was a representative agrarian who built Jeffersonian Democracy around the notion that farmers are "the most valuable citizens" and the truest republicans.[PARAGRAPH:2]The philosophical roots of agrarianism include European and Chinese philosophers. The Chinese School of Agrarianism was a philosophy that advocated peasant utopian communalism and egalitarianism. This influenced European intellectuals like François Quesnay, an avid Confucianist and advocate of China's agrarian policies, forming the French agrarian philosophy of Physiocracy. The Physiocrats, along with the ideas of John Locke and the Romantic Era, formed the basis of modern European and American agrarianism.[PARAGRAPH:2]Secondly, the term "agrarianism" means political proposals for land redistribution, specifically the distribution of land from the rich to the poor or landless. This terminology is common in many countries, and originated from the "Lex Sempronia Agraria" or "agrarian laws" of Rome in 133 BC, imposed by Tiberius Gracchus, that seized the lands of the rich and distributed them to the poor. This definition of agrarianism is commonly known as "agrarian reform".[PARAGRAPH:2]In societies influenced by Confucianism, the farmer was considered an esteemed productive member of society, whereas merchants who made money were looked down upon. In eighteenth- and nineteenth-century England, the word identified any land reform movement that sought to redistribute cultivated lands equally. Today, the word has largely shed this radical political meaning. Instead, agrarianism points to a collection of political, philosophical, and literary ideas that together tend to describe farm life in ideal terms.

Allows the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Persecution[COLOR_REVERT] of other religions.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Animism (from Latin anima "soul, life") is a set of beliefs based on the existence of non-human "spiritual beings" or similar kinds of embodied principles.[PARAGRAPH:2]Animism encompasses the beliefs that there is no separation between the spiritual and physical (or material) world, and souls or spirits exist, not only in humans, but also in all other animals, plants, rocks, geographic features such as mountains or rivers, or other entities of the natural environment. Animism may further attribute souls to abstract concepts such as words, true names, or metaphors in mythology. Examples of Animism can be found in forms of Shinto, Serer, Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism, Pantheism, Paganism, and Neopaganism.[PARAGRAPH:2]Throughout European history, philosophers such as Aristotle and Thomas Aquinas, among others, contemplated the possibility that souls exist in animals, plants, and people; however, the currently accepted definition of animism was only developed in the 19th century by Sir Edward Tylor, who created it as "one of anthropology's earliest concepts, if not the first".[PARAGRAPH:2]According to the anthropologist Tim Ingold, animism shares similarities to totemism but differs in its focus on individual spirit beings which help to perpetuate life, whereas totemism more typically holds that there is a primary source, such as the land itself or the ancestors, who provide the basis to life. Certain indigenous religious groups such as the Australian Aborigines are more typically totemic, whereas others like the Inuit are more typically animistic in their worldview.

[TAB]An Autocracy is a system of government in which a supreme political power is concentrated in the hands of one person, whose decisions are subject to neither external legal restraints nor regularized mechanisms of popular control (except perhaps for the implicit threat of coup d'état or mass insurrection).[PARAGRAPH:2]Autocracy is any form of government in which one person is the supreme power within the state. It is derived from the Greek "auto" ("self") and "kratos" ("rule"), and may be translated as "one who rules by himself". It is distinct from oligarchy ("rule by the few") and democracy ("rule by the people"). Like "despot", "tyrant", "strongman" and "dictator", "autocrat" has become a loaded word with a negative value judgment in contemporary English usage.[PARAGRAPH:2]The term autokrator is employed in antiquity to translate the Latin imperator into Greek. It was the primary word used by grecophones to the Roman Emperor during the later Roman Empire through the seventh century AD and continued to be used in the Byzantine period, although it lost favor to Sebastos ("augustus") and Basileus (obscure: prob. "chieftain;" later "king") as synonyms for "emperor". This use remains current in the modern Greek language, where the term is used for anyone holding the title "emperor," regardless of the actual power of the monarch.

[TAB]Capitalism is an economic system that is based on private ownership of the means of production and the creation of goods or services for profit. Competitive markets, wage labor, capital accumulation, voluntary exchange, and personal finance are also considered capitalistic. Competitive markets, capital accumulation, voluntary exchange, and personal finance may be parts of capitalism, however in practice there are never pure capitalist economies. Often, other non-capitalist systems such as market socialism and worker cooperatives retain aspects of capitalism. There are multiple variants of capitalism, including laissez-faire and state capitalism. Capitalism is considered to have been applied in a variety of historical cases, varying in time, geography, politics, and culture. There is general agreement that capitalism became dominant in the Western world following the demise of feudalism.[PARAGRAPH:2]Economists, political economists and historians have taken different perspectives on the analysis of capitalism. Economists usually emphasize the degree to which government does not have control over markets (laissez faire), as well as the importance of property rights. Most political economists emphasize private property as well, in addition to power relations, wage labor, class, and the uniqueness of capitalism as a historical formation. The extent to which different markets are free, as well as the rules defining private property, is a matter of politics and policy. Many states have what are termed mixed economies, referring to the varying degree of planned and market-driven elements in a state's economic system. A number of political ideologies have emerged in support of various types of capitalism, the most prominent being economic liberalism.[PARAGRAPH:2]The term capitalism gradually spread throughout the Western world in the 19th and 20th centuries largely through the writings of Karl Marx. However, it is the default economic system and it has its roots tracing back to the beginning of recorded history.

[TAB]Central planning represents an economy completely controlled, owned and planned by the government, otherwise known as state capitalism. Under a centrally planned economy, all labor, capital, production, agriculture, utilities, and finances are run by the government, and all service businesses are owned by the government. Because there are no private companies, no trade exists. Centrally planned economies are able to concentrate their resources on major projects such as world wonders and world projects, but are very costly to maintain.

[TAB]A city-state is an independent or autonomous entity whose territory consists of a city which is not administered as a part of another local government. A city-state can also be defined as a central city and its surrounding villages, which together follow the same law, have one form of government, and share languages, religious beliefs, and ways of life. Today, only three independent, sovereign city-states exist: Monaco, Singapore, and the Vatican City.

[TAB]The English noun "Commonwealth" originally dates from the fifteenth century. The term literally meant "common well-being". Thus commonwealth originally meant a state governed for the common good as opposed to an authoritarian state governed for the benefit of a given class of owners. [PARAGRAPH:2]Today the term is more general and means a political community. When capitalised, "Commonwealth" normally refers to the 53 member Commonwealth of Nations - formerly the "British Commonwealth" - a loose confederation of nations formerly members of the British Empire.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Le terme anglais "Commonwealth" remonte au quinzième siècle. Il signifie littéralement "bien-être de tous". Commonwealth voulait donc désigner un état gouverné pour le bien de tous, par opposition à un état autoritaire gouverné pour le bénéfice d'une certaine classe possédante. [PARAGRAPH:2]Aujourd'hui, le terme est plus général et désigne une communauté politique. Le Commonwealth fait normalement référence aux 53 nations qui faisaient à l'origine partie du Commonwealth britannique, une confédération disparate de pays issus de l'ancien empire britannique.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der englische Begriff "Commonwealth" datiert ursprünglich aus dem 15. Jahrhundert und bedeutet wörtlich übersetzt etwa "Gemeinwohl". Er bezeichnete ursprünglich einen Staat, dessen Regierung vornehmlich auf das Wohl der Gemeinschaft abzielt, im Gegensatz zum autoritären Staat, dessen Regierung vor allem auf das Wohlergehen einer bestimmten Klasse von Grundbesitzern und sonstigen Eigentümern hinarbeitet. [PARAGRAPH:2]Heute wird der Begriff allgemeiner verwendet und beschreibt eine politische Staatengemeinschaft. Wenn man vom "Commonwealth" spricht, ist damit nun normalerweise das aus 53 Mitgliedsstaaten gebildete "Commonwealth of Nations" - ehemals "British Commonwealth" genannt - gemeint, ein freiwilliger Bund unabhängiger Staaten, die früher zum British Empire gehörten.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]La parola inglese "Commonwealth" risale al quindicesimo secolo. Il termine significava letteralmente "benessere comune". Quindi originariamente commonwealth stava a indicare uno stato governato per il bene comune, in opposizione a uno stato autoritario governato per il benessere di una data classe. [PARAGRAPH:2]Oggi il termine è più generico e indica una comunità politica. Quando è maiuscolo, "Commonwealth" di solito si riferisce al Commonwealth delle Nazioni, composto da 53 membri e una volta conosciuto come Commonwealth britannico: una confederazione di nazioni che facevano precedentemente parte dell'impero britannico.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]El término inglés "Commonwealth", que tiene su origen en el siglo XV, significa literalmente "bienestar común", y en sus orígenes hacía referencia a un tipo de estado cuyo gobierno persigue el bien común, frente a un estado autoritario que persigue el beneficio de una determinada clase social. [PARAGRAPH:2]Hoy el término es más general y alude a una comunidad política. Cuando se escribe con mayúsculas, "Commonwealth" hace referencia a la "Commonwealth of Nations" de 53 miembros, antes denominada "British Commonwealth of Nations", una confederación laxa que engloba a las naciones que pertenecieron al Imperio Británico.

TEXT.English: [TAB]A dynasty is a sequence of rulers considered as members of the same family. Historians traditionally consider many sovereign states' history within a framework of successive dynasties, e.g., Ancient Egypt, Persian Empire, and Imperial China. Much of European political history is dominated by dynasties such as the Carolingians, the Capetians, the Bourbons, the Habsburgs, the Stuarts, the Hohenzollerns and the Romanovs. Until the 19th century, it was taken for granted that a legitimate function of a monarch was to aggrandize his dynasty: that is, to increase the territory, wealth and power of family members.

[TAB]Egalitarianism (from French égal, meaning "equal") is a trend of thought that favors equality among living entities. Egalitarian doctrines maintain that all humans are equal in fundamental worth or social status, according to The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy. The Cultural theory of risk holds egalitarianism as defined by (1) a negative attitude towards rules and principles, and (2) a positive attitude towards group decision-making, with fatalism termed as its opposite. According to the Merriam-Webster Dictionary, the term has two distinct definitions in modern English. It is defined either as a political doctrine that all people should be treated as equals and have the same political, economic, social, and civil rights or as a social philosophy advocating the removal of economic inequalities among people or the decentralization of power. Some sources define egalitarianism as the point of view that equality reflects the natural state of humanity.

Allows the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Persecution[COLOR_REVERT] of other religions.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Fanaticism is strict adherence to a specific set of theological doctrines. These doctrines are usually considered to be of much greater importance and relevance than any man-made laws; in many cases a fanatical state adopts them as state law and strives to impose them on other civilizations as well. Other religions are regarded with disdain or even open hostility. Alternatively, some fanatical states prefer to isolate themselves from the heathens and secularism of the world.

[TAB]Under the feudal conditions for holding land in the medieval period, most peasants and freemen were liable to provide one man of suitable age per family for military duty when required by either the king or the local lord. The levies raised in this way fought as infantry under local superiors. Although the exact laws varied greatly depending on the country and the period, generally these levies were only obliged to fight for one to three months. Most were subsistence farmers, and it was in everyone's interest to send the men home for harvest-time.

[TAB]A mercenary is a person who takes part in an armed conflict, who is not a national or a party to the conflict and is "motivated to take part in the hostilities by the desire for private gain." The term "mercenary" is also used to describe the army itself.

[TAB]The most basic method of organizing an armed defense for the community is that of the militia. In primitive societies, every adult male is expected to fight (with varying competence) to either protect the village or to raid and harass neighbors. In more settled and organized societies, the duty of forming a militia tends to fall on volunteers armed and trained at community expense, or on elite classes of citizens who can afford their own weapons.[PARAGRAPH:2]Militia have the strategic advantages of being numerous, cheap to maintain from the central government's perspective, and of having reliable local loyalties that make them difficult to suborn. The large, corresponding disadvantages are that they are often less competent than more professional forces, difficult to keep in the field for long periods, and reluctant to fight far from their homes.

[TAB]In the modern western countries, the European "Age of Sail" is the period in which international trade and naval warfare were both dominated by sailing ships. The age of sail mostly coincided with the age of discovery, from the 15th to the 18th century. After the 17th century, English naval maps stopped using the term of British Sea for the English Channel. From 15th to the 18th centuries, the period saw square rigged sailing ships[26] carry European settlers to many parts of the world in one of the most important human migrations in recorded history. This period was marked by extensive exploration and colonization efforts on the part of European kingdoms. The sextant, developed in the 18th century, made more accurate charting of nautical position possible.

[TAB]Belligerent military occupation occurs when one nation's military occupies all or part of the territory of another nation or recognized belligerent. [PARAGRAPH:2]In most wars some territory of the losing side is placed under the authority of the hostile army. Most military occupations end with the cessation of hostilities. In some cases the occupied territory is returned and in others the land remains under the control of the occupying power but usually not as militarily occupied territory. The latter was the case of Germany after WWII, which ended up being split into two different nations.
TEXT.French: [TAB]L'occupation militaire désigne la présence d'une armée étrangère sur tout ou partie du territoire d'une autre nation ou d'un belligérant reconnu. [PARAGRAPH:2]Dans la plupart des guerres, certains territoires du pays vaincu sont placés sous l'autorité d'une armée ennemie. La plupart des occupations militaires se terminent avec la cessation des hostilités. Dans certains cas, le territoire occupé est rendu et dans d'autres, il reste sous le contrôle de la puissance occupante, mais plus en tant que territoire occupé militairement. La dernière occupation fut celle de l'Allemagne après la Seconde Guerre mondiale, qui se termina par sa division en deux pays distincts.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine kriegerische militärische Besatzung tritt dann ein, wenn die militärischen Streitkräfte einer Nation das Territorium einer anderen Nation oder eines Kriegsgegners vollständig oder teilweise besetzen. [PARAGRAPH:2]In den meisten Kriegen wurde ein Teil des Territoriums der Verliererseite der Befehlsgewalt der feindlichen Militärs unterstellt. Dabei beendeten die militärischen Besatzungen in der Regel gleichzeitig auch die Feindseligkeiten zwischen den Kriegsparteien. In manchen Fällen wurde das Besatzungsgebiet später wieder zurückgegeben, in anderen verblieb es in der Hand der Besatzungsmacht, normalerweise aber nicht mehr als militärisch besetztes Territorium. Letzteres ereignete sich nach dem 2. Weltkrieg in Deutschland und endete damit, dass Deutschland bis zur Wiedervereinigung im Jahr 1990 in zwei verschiedene Staaten aufgeteilt war.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]L'occupazione militare si ha quando l'esercito di una nazione occupa tutto o parte del territorio di un'altra nazione o fazione ostile. [PARAGRAPH:2]In molte guerre parte del territorio della fazione perdente viene posto sotto l'autorità dell'esercito ostile. La maggior parte delle occupazioni militari terminano con la cessazione delle ostilità. In alcuni casi il territorio occupato viene restituito, mentre in altri rimane sotto il controllo della potenza occupante, anche se solitamente non come territorio occupato militarmente. Questo fu il caso della Germania dopo la Seconda Guerra Mondiale, che finì con l'essere divisa in due diverse nazioni.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]La ocupación militar se produce cuando un ejército beligerante de una nación ocupa todo o parte del territorio de otra nación. [PARAGRAPH:2]En muchas guerras, parte del territorio del bando derrotado es sometido a la autoridad del ejército hostil. La mayor parte de las ocupaciones militares finalizan con el cese de las hostilidades. En algunos casos, el territorio ocupado es devuelto, pero en otros la zona permanece bajo control de la potencia enemiga, aunque ya no como territorio ocupado militarmente. El último fue el caso de Alemania tras la II Guerra Mundial, que acabó siendo divida entre dos naciones diferentes.

TEXT.English: Allows the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Persecution[COLOR_REVERT] of other religions.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]An organized religion is one in which there is a central authority which interprets or determines theology, which decides which ceremonies are to be performed at which times, and which appoints priests or holy men to keep worshipers on the correct path. The central authority may be a rigid and powerful hierarchy with great religious and secular power, or it may be a group of elders who meet periodically to discuss matters of importance to their members. [PARAGRAPH:2]An organized religion can be a mighty thing, more powerful than kings or despots. Its followers may provide it with great wealth, and may construct mighty edifices in their gods' honor. Usually, however, organized religions are less powerful than that and must live in uneasy harmony with the local secular governments.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Une religion organisée dispose d'une autorité centralisée qui interprète et détermine la théologie, qui décide quand et comment sont organisées les cérémonies du culte et qui se charge de nommer les prêtres et autres hommes d'église qui dirigeront les fidèles. L'autorité centrale peut prendre la forme d'une hiérarchie rigide et puissante ayant un pouvoir à la fois religieux et laïc. Elle peut aussi être composée d'un groupe d'anciens qui se réunissent régulièrement pour discuter des problèmes que rencontre leur communauté. [PARAGRAPH:2]Une religion organisée peut être puissante et avoir davantage de pouvoir qu'un roi ou qu'un despote. Ses fidèles peuvent la rendre riche et bâtir des édifices majestueux en l'honneur de leur Dieu. Cependant, les religions organisées sont rarement aussi puissantes et doivent généralement vivre tant bien que mal en harmonie avec un véritable pouvoir laïque.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Eine organisierte Religion hat eine zentrale Autorität, die für die Interpretation der Theologie, die Liturgie, die Priesterweihe und Heiligsprechungen verantwortlich ist. Diese zentrale Autorität ist nicht selten eine einflussreiche Behörde mit beträchtlicher geistlicher und weltlicher Macht. [PARAGRAPH:2]Organisierte Religionen konnten sehr mächtig werden, mächtiger noch als Könige oder Despoten. Oft häuften ihre Gläubigen große Reichtümer an und errichteten zu Ehren ihres Gottes prächtige Gebäude. Heute ist der politische und religiöse Einfluss organisierter Religionen allerdings eher gering.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]In una organizzazione religiosa esiste un'autorità centrale che interpreta o determina la teologia, che decide quando e quali cerimonie devono essere eseguite, che nomina i sacerdoti o gli uomini santi per mantenere i fedeli sulla retta via. L'autorità centrale può essere una gerarchia potente e rigida di grandi religioni e potere secolare, oppure può essere rappresentata da un gruppo di anziani che si incontrano periodicamente per discutere questioni importanti. [PARAGRAPH:2]Una organizzazione religiosa può rappresentare un grande potere, più di quello di un re o un despota: i seguaci possono fornire ricchezze e finanziare la realizzazione di grandi edifici in onore degli dei. Tuttavia, le organizzazioni religiose sono meno potenti e devono vivere in una difficile armonia con i governi locali laici.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]Una religión organizada es una en la que existe una autoridad central que interpreta o establece la teología, decide qué ceremonias se llevan a cabo y nombra a los sacerdotes u hombres santos encargados de mantener al rebaño en el recto camino. La autoridad central puede ser una jerarquía rígida y poderosa dotada de gran poder religioso y secular o puede estar formada por un consejo de ancianos que se reúne periódicamente para debatir todos los asuntos concernientes a sus fieles. [PARAGRAPH:2]Las religiones organizadas pueden ser muy poderosas, más incluso que los reyes o los déspotas. Sus seguidores pueden proporcionarle enormes riquezas y erigir impresionantes edificios en honor a sus dioses. Sin embargo, lo normal es que no sean tan poderosas y se vean obligadas a convivir en un estado de complicada armonía con los poderes seculares.

TEXT.English: Religious Victory:[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Make sure there are 15 pagan temples in the world[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Control ten wonders that require no state religion[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Don't allow more than half of your cities to have a religion[NEWLINE]Allows construction of [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Pagan Temples[COLOR_REVERT] and also the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Ishtar Gate[COLOR_REVERT], [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Machu Picchu[COLOR_REVERT], the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Colosseum[COLOR_REVERT], the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Colossus[COLOR_REVERT], the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Great Cothan[COLOR_REVERT], the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Great Library[COLOR_REVERT], the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Great Lighthouse[COLOR_REVERT], the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Great Sphinx[COLOR_REVERT], the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Oracle[COLOR_REVERT], the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Parthenon[COLOR_REVERT], the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Pyramids[COLOR_REVERT] and the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Temple of Artemis[COLOR_REVERT] World Wonders. [PARAGRAPH:2]A pantheon (literally "a temple of all gods", "of or common to all gods") is a set of all the gods of a particular polytheistic religion or mythology.[PARAGRAPH:2]Max Weber's 1922 opus, Economy and Society, discusses the link between a pantheon of gods and the development of monotheism.[PARAGRAPH:2]Pantheon can also refer to a temple or sacred building explicitly dedicated to "all deities", avoiding the difficulty of giving an exhaustive list. The most known such structure is the Pantheon of Rome, built in the year 27 BC. The building was dedicated to "all gods" as a gesture embracing the religious syncretism in the increasingly multicultural Roman Empire, with subjects worshipping gods from many cultures and traditions. The building was later renovated for use as a Christian church in 609 under Pope Boniface IV.[PARAGRAPH:2]Since the 16th century "pantheon" also refers in a secular sense to the set of a society's exalted persons. For example "Mick Jagger was exalted into the pantheon of rock megastars".

[TAB]An early version of the welfare state appeared in China during the Song Dynasty in the 11th century. Prime Minister Wang Anshi believed that the state was responsible for providing its citizens the essentials for a decent living standard. Accordingly, under his direction the state initiated agricultural loans to relieve the farming peasants. He appointed boards to regulate wages and plan pensions for the aged and unemployed. These reforms were known as the "new laws," New Policies, or xin fa.[PARAGRAPH:2]Modern welfare states developed through a gradual process beginning in the late 19th century and continuing through the 20th. They differed from previous schemes of poverty relief due to their relatively universal coverage. The development of social insurance in Germany under Bismarck was particularly influential. Some schemes, like those in Scandinavia, were based largely in the development of autonomous, mutualist provision of benefits. Others were founded on state provision. The term was not, however, applied to all states offering social protection. The sociologist T.H. Marshall identified the welfare state as a distinctive combination of democracy, welfare and capitalism.[PARAGRAPH:2]Examples of early welfare states in the modern world are Sweden (Folkhemmet), Germany, the Netherlands, and New Zealand in the 1930s. Germany is generally held to be the first social welfare state. Changed attitudes in reaction to the Great Depression were instrumental in the move to the welfare state in many countries, a harbinger of new times where "cradle-to-grave" services became a reality after the poverty of the Depression. During the Great Depression, it was seen as an alternative "middle way" between communism and fascism. In the period following the Second World War, many countries in Europe moved from partial or selective provision of social services to relatively comprehensive coverage of the population.[PARAGRAPH:2]The activities of present-day welfare states extend to the provision of both cash welfare benefits (such as old-age pensions or unemployment benefits) and in-kind welfare services (such as health or childcare services). Through these provisions, welfare states can affect the distribution of wellbeing and personal autonomy among their citizens, as well as influencing how their citizens consume and how they spend their time.[PARAGRAPH:2]After the discovery and inflow of the oil revenue, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, and United Arab Emirates all became welfare states. However, the services are strictly for citizens and these countries do not accept immigrants; even those born in these countries do not qualify for citizenship unless they are of the parentage belonging to their respective countries.[PARAGRAPH:2]The beginning of the modern welfare state was in 1911 when David Lloyd George suggested everyone in work should pay national insurance contribution for unemployment and health benefits from work.[PARAGRAPH:2]In 1942, the 'Social Insurance and Allied Services' was created by Sir William Beveridge in order to aid those who were in need of help, or in poverty. Beverage worked as a volunteer for the poor, and set up national insurance. He stated that 'All people of working age should pay a weekly national insurance contribution. In return, benefits would be paid to people who were sick, unemployed, retired or widowed.' The basic assumptions of the report were the National Health Service, which provided free health care to the UK. The Universal Child Benefit was a scheme to to give child benefits, which encouraged people to have children so they could afford to keep them alive and not for them to starve to death. This was particularly useful after the second world war, where the population in England declined, so encouragement for new babies was encouraged, which sparked the baby boom. The impact of the report was huge and 600,000 copies were made. He recommended to the government that they should find ways of tackling the five giants, being Want, Disease, Ignorance, Squalor and Idleness. He argued to cure these problems, the government should provide adequate income to people, adequate health care, adequate education, adequate housing and adequate employment. Before 1939, health care had to be paid for, this was done through a vast network of friendly societies, trade unions and other insurance companies which counted the vast majority of the UK working population as members. These friendly societies provided insurance for sickness, unemployment and invalidity, therefore providing people with an income when they were unable to work. But because of the 1942 Berveridge Report, in 5th July 1948, the National Insurance Act, National Assistance Act and National Health Service Act came into force, thus this is the day that the modern UK welfare state was founded.

Allows construction of the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Statue of Liberty[COLOR_REVERT] World Wonder.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]In a republic, the head of state is not a monarch and there are no legal privileges for the nobility. The exact form of government can vary widely, from absolute despotism to direct democracy, but the most important difference between a republic and any form of monarchy is the much-diminished role of family and lineage in government.[PARAGRAPH:2]Before the French Revolution, a republic in Europe was an aberration. The state enjoyed none of the external security provided by royal family ties. Internally, the succession was decided to some extent by merit, even if this often meant merely that the man with the best ability to take power would do so.

[TAB]"Resettlement" literally means the transportation of a group of people to a new settlement and the populating of a new area. Although migration has featured throughout human history and prehistory, the word settler (synonymous with terms like pioneers and colonists) is often used in relation to modern or early modern history. [PARAGRAPH:2]The reason for emigration of settlers varies, but often includes one or more factors such as: personal economic hardship; social, cultural, ethnic, or religious persecution; political oppression; or policies aimed at encouraging foreign settlement.
TEXT.French: [TAB]"Repeuplement" signifie littéralement amener un groupe de personnes dans une nouvelle implantation pour peupler une zone. Bien que la migration soit une constante de la préhistoire et de l'histoire de l'humanité, le mot colon (synonyme de pionnier) est souvent utilisé en relation avec l'histoire moderne ou contemporaine. [PARAGRAPH:2]Les raisons qui poussent à émigrer sont nombreuses, mais on retrouve souvent les difficultés économiques personnelles, les persécutions sociales, ethniques ou religieuses, l'oppression politique, ou des politiques encourageant la colonisation.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Begriff "Umsiedlung" beschreibt den Umzug einer Gruppe von Menschen in ein neues Siedlungsgebiet bzw. die Bevölkerung neuer Gebiete. Während es derartige "Völkerwanderungen" in der gesamten Menschheitsgeschichte gegeben hat, wird der davon abgeleitete Begriff "Siedler" (Synonym für Pionier und Kolonist) häufig in Bezug auf die moderne bzw. frühmoderne Geschichte verwendet. [PARAGRAPH:2]Es gibt unterschiedliche Gründe für die Ab- bzw. Auswanderung von Siedlern, meist spielen dabei jedoch folgende Faktoren eine Rolle: persönliches bzw. wirtschaftliches Elend, soziale, kulturelle, ethnische oder religiöse Verfolgung, politische Unterdrückung oder die politische Förderung fremder Siedlungen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]"Risistemazione" sta a indicare il trasporto di un gruppo di persone in un nuovo insediamento e il popolamento di una nuova zona. Anche se le migrazioni hanno avuto luogo in tutta la storia e preistoria umana, la parola colonizzatore (o anche pioniere o colono) è spesso utilizzata in relazione alla storia moderna. [PARAGRAPH:2]Le ragioni per l'emigrazione dei coloni sono diverse, ma spesso includono uno o più fattori come: forti problemi economici; persecuzione sociale, culturale, etnica o religiosa; oppressione politica, oppure politiche che incoraggiano l'insediamento all'estero.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]El "reasentamiento" consiste en el traslado de un grupo de personas a un nuevo enclave para poblar una nueva zona. Aunque la migración ha existido en toda la historia, e incluso en la prehistoria, el término colono, en ocasiones sinónimo de pionero, se suele utilizar en contextos de la historia moderna o contemporánea. [PARAGRAPH:2]Los motivos de la migración colonial son variados, pero a menudo incluyen dos o más factores, como penurias económicas, persecución social, cultural, étnica o religiosa, opresión política o políticas potenciadoras de la emigración o la inmigración.

TEXT.English: Allows the [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]Persecution[COLOR_REVERT] of other religions.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB]Scholasticism is a method of critical thought which dominated teaching by the academics (scholastics, or schoolmen) of medieval universities in Europe from about 1100-1500, and a program of employing that method in articulating and defending orthodoxy in an increasingly pluralistic context. It originated as an outgrowth of, and a departure from, Christian monastic schools.[PARAGRAPH:2]Not so much a philosophy or a theology as a method of learning, scholasticism places a strong emphasis on dialectical reasoning to extend knowledge by inference, and to resolve contradictions. Scholastic thought is also known for rigorous conceptual analysis and the careful drawing of distinctions. In the classroom and in writing, it often takes the form of explicit disputation: a topic drawn from the tradition is broached in the form of a question, opponents' responses are given, a counterproposal is argued and opponent's arguments rebutted. Because of its emphasis on rigorous dialectical method, scholasticism was eventually applied to many other fields of study.[PARAGRAPH:2]As a program, scholasticism began as an attempt at harmonization on the part of medieval Christian thinkers: to harmonize the various authorities of their own tradition, and to reconcile Christian theology with classical and late antiquity philosophy, especially that of Aristotle but also of Neoplatonism.[PARAGRAPH:2]The main figures of scholasticism historically are Anselm of Canterbury, Peter Abelard, Alexander of Hales, Albertus Magnus, Duns Scotus, William of Ockham, Bonaventure and Thomas Aquinas. Thomas Aquinas's masterwork, the Summa Theologica, is often seen as the highest fruit of Scholasticism. Important work in the scholastic tradition has been carried on, however, well past Aquinas' time, for instance by Francisco Suárez and Molina, and also among Lutheran and Reformed thinkers.

Religious Victory:[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Tolerance: Control the temples of seven different religions[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Humanism: Make sure there are 20 universities controlled by secular civilizations[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Modernization: Be the first to enter the Industrial and Modern eras[PARAGRAPH:2][TAB]Secularism is the principle of separation between government institutions and the persons mandated to represent the State from religious institutions and religious dignitaries. In one sense, secularism may assert the right to be free from religious rule and teachings, and the right to freedom from governmental imposition of religion upon the people within a state that is neutral on matters of belief. (See also separation of church and state and Laïcité.) In another sense, it refers to the view that human activities and decisions, especially political ones, should be unbiased by religious influence. Some scholars are now arguing that the very idea of secularism will change.[PARAGRAPH:2]Secularism draws its intellectual roots from Greek and Roman philosophers such as Marcus Aurelius and Epicurus; medieval Muslim polymaths such as Ibn Rushd; Enlightenment thinkers such as Denis Diderot, Voltaire, Baruch Spinoza, John Locke, James Madison, Thomas Jefferson, and Thomas Paine; and more recent freethinkers, agnostics, and atheists such as Robert Ingersoll and Bertrand Russell.[PARAGRAPH:2]The purposes and arguments in support of secularism vary widely. In European laicism, it has been argued that secularism is a movement toward modernization, and away from traditional religious values (also known as secularization). This type of secularism, on a social or philosophical level, has often occurred while maintaining an official state church or other state support of religion. In the United States, some argue that state secularism has served to a greater extent to protect religion and the religious from governmental interference, while secularism on a social level is less prevalent. Within countries as well, differing political movements support secularism for varying reasons.

[TAB]As nations grow large and prosperous, it is natural for them to expand their permanent cadre of armed forces into a professional organization that exists through times of both war and peace. Soldiers in these standing armies are paid for service on much the same basis as civilian employees would be. The rise of a professional military is usually accompanied by the rise of a dedicated bureaucracy or staff, which makes management of manpower and the military-industrial complex more efficient. Easy access into a volunteer military from citizens of all classes also makes the military an organ of social cohesion.

[TAB]The term "subjugation" is used to describe the policy of a nation's dominance over other lands. This doctrine has been frequently employed for economic exploitation in which an imperialist power makes use of other countries as sources of raw materials and cheap labor, shaping their economies to suit its own interests and keeping their people in poverty. [PARAGRAPH:2]Sometimes subjugation even refers to the acceptance, by the colonised, of the culture or doctrines of the coloniser as intrinsically more worthy or superior.
TEXT.French: [TAB]Le terme d'Assujettissement fait référence à la politique de dominance d'une nation. Cette doctrine a souvent été employée pour l'exploitation économique d'un pays par un autre : un pouvoir impérialiste utilise d'autres pays en tant que sources de matières premières et de main-d'oeuvre bon marché, ajuste leur économie selon ses propres intérêts et maintient les gens dans la pauvreté. [PARAGRAPH:2]Parfois, l'Assujettissement fait référence à l'acceptation par les peuples colonisés de la culture ou des doctrines des colonisateurs, considérées comme meilleures ou supérieures.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Begriff "Unterwerfung" beschreibt die politischen Bestrebungen einer Nation, andere Länder beherrschen zu wollen. Diese Doktrin wurde häufig zur Realisierung wirtschaftlicher Ausbeutung eingesetzt, wobei die Kolonialmacht andere Länder als Quellen für seltene Rohstoffe und billige Arbeitskräfte missbrauchte, deren Wirtschaft sie dann so gestaltete, dass sie zu den eigenen Interessen passte und schlussendlich die Einheimischen in ihrer Armut beließ. [PARAGRAPH:2]Manchmal wird mit "Unterwerfung" allerdings auch der Umstand bezeichnet, dass die Kolonisierten die Kultur oder Lehren der Kolonialmacht als "wertvoller" oder "besser" akzeptieren und würdigen.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]Il termine "sottomissione" viene usato per descrivere il dominio di una nazione su altre terre. Questa dottrina è stata spesso usata per lo sfruttamento economico: una potenza imperialista sfrutta altri paesi come fonti di materie prime e lavoro a basso costo, modellando le loro economie a favore dei propri interessei e mantenendone le popolazioni in povertà. [PARAGRAPH:2]Alle volte la sottomissione fa addirittura riferimento all'accettazione, da parte dei colonizzati, di una presunta e intrinseca superiorità della cultura dei colonizzatori.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]El término "subyugación" se utiliza para describir la política de dominio de una nación sobre otros territorios. Esta doctrina se ha empleado frecuentemente para describir la explotación económica que realiza una potencia imperialista cuando utiliza a otros países como fuentes de materias primas y mano de obra barata, modelando sus economías según sus propios intereses y manteniendo a sus gentes en la pobreza. [PARAGRAPH:2]A veces la subyugación también alude a la aceptación por parte de la colonia de la cultura o las doctrinas de la potencia colonial como intrínsecamente superiores.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Self-sufficiency is the state of not requiring any aid, support, or interaction, for survival; it is therefore a type of personal or collective autonomy. On a national scale, a totally self-sufficient economy that does not trade with the outside world is called an autarky.[PARAGRAPH:2]The term self-sufficiency is usually applied to varieties of sustainable living in which nothing is consumed outside of what is produced by the self-sufficient individuals. Examples of attempts at self-sufficiency in North America include simple living, homesteading, off-the-grid, survivalism, DIY ethic and the back-to-the-land movement.[PARAGRAPH:2]Practices that enable or aid self-sufficiency include autonomous building, permaculture, sustainable agriculture, and renewable energy.[PARAGRAPH:2]The term is also applied to limited forms of self-sufficiency, for example growing one's own food or becoming economically independent of state subsidies.[PARAGRAPH:2]The entire population of the world was, at one time, self sufficient. They made their own clothing, tools, weapons, boats, huts, and food. They used gathering, hunting, herding and farming to find/hunt/grow their own food. As the human population of he world grew, the wild food supply dwindled. People began to rely on herding and farming more; reling less upon gathering and hunting. In modern times, automated food production on farms makes food. The vast populations now depend on a fewer farmers to make their food for them. Many in developed nations now depend on job salaries to buy food, clothes, and shelter, rather than making these things from raw materials found in the environment. But in a few places in the world, native societies continue to be self sufficient, never having given up their traditional ways of food gathering and food making. Because these native peoples have no jobs and make no salaries, they are often listed as unemployed.

[TAB]Totalitarianism (or totalitarian rule) is a political system where the state recognizes no limits to its authority and strives to regulate every aspect of public and private life wherever feasible. Totalitarian regimes stay in political power through an all-encompassing propaganda campaign, which is disseminated through the state-controlled mass media, a single party that is often marked by political repression, personality cultism, control over the economy, regulation and restriction of speech, mass surveillance, and widespread use of terror. It is not synonymous with dictatorship, as authoritarian regimes also exhibit dictatorial features, but do not create an all-controlling, all-politicised society. Furthermore, non-dictatorial governments and societies are sometimes denounced as having totalitarian features, including democratic socialism, capitalism and liberal democracy.[PARAGRAPH:2]The concept of totalitarianism was first developed in a positive sense in the 1920s by the Italian fascists. The concept became prominent in Western anti-communist political discourse during the Cold War era in order to highlight perceived similarities between Nazi Germany and other fascist regimes on the one hand, and Soviet communism on the other.[PARAGRAPH:2]Aside from fascist and Stalinist movements that are totalitarian, there have been other movements that are totalitarian. The leader of the historic Spanish reactionary conservative movement called the Spanish Confederation of the Autonomous Right declared his intention to "give Spain a true unity, a new spirit, a totalitarian polity..." and went on to say "Democracy is not an end but a means to the conquest of the new state. When the time comes, either parliament submits or we will eliminate it." Baathist Iraq was distinctly ultra-nationalist and totalitarian, and has been dubbed by historian Stanley G. Payne as "the closest" reproduction of the Third Reich. Several revolutionary fundamentalist regimes have been pointed out as totalitarian, including post-revolutionary Iran.

[TAB]In classical politics, a tyrant (Greek, tyrannos) is one who illegally seizes and controls a governmental power in a polis. Tyrants were a group of individuals who took over many Greek poleis during the uprising of the middle classes in the sixth and seventh centuries BC, ousting the aristocratic governments. Plato and Aristotle define a tyrant as, "one who rules without law, looks to his own advantage rather than that of his subjects, and uses extreme and cruel tactics -- against his own people as well as others". During the sixth and seventh centuries BC, tyranny was often looked upon as an intermediate stage between narrow oligarchy and more democratic forms of polity. However, in the late fifth and fourth centuries, a new kind of tyrant, the military dictator arose, specifically in Sicily. In ancient Greece, tyrants were influential opportunists that came to power by securing the support of different factions of a deme. The word "tyrannos", possibly pre-Greek, Pelasgian or eastern in origin, then carried no ethical censure; it simply referred to anyone, good or bad, who obtained executive power in a polis by unconventional means. Support for the tyrants came from the growing middle class and from the peasants who had no land or were in debt to the wealthy land owners. It is true that they had no legal right to rule, but the people preferred them over kings or the aristocracy. The Greek tyrants stayed in power by using mercenary soldiers from outside of their respective city-state. To mock tyranny, Thales wrote that the strangest thing to see is "an aged tyrant" meaning that tyrants do not have the public support to survive for long. In Corinth, growing wealth from colonial enterprises, and the wider horizons brought about by the export of wine and oil, together with the new experiences of the Eastern Mediterranean brought back by returning mercenary hoplites employed overseas allowed Cypselus, the first tyrant of Corinth in the 7th century BC, to overthrow the aristocratic power of the dominant but unpopular Bacchiadae, who were killed, executed, driven out and exiled in 657 BC. Corinth prospered economically under his rule and Cypselus manages to rule without a bodyguard but when he managed to bequeath his position to his son, Periander, whose position was less secure, his son required a bodyguard of mercenary soldiers personally loyal to himself. Nevertheless, under Cypselus and Periander, Corinth extended and tightened her control over her colonial enterprises, and exports of Corinthian pottery flourished. However, tyrants seldom succeeded in establishing an untroubled line of succession. Perianders successor was less fortunate and was expelled, Corinth was ruled by a lack-lustre oligarchy, and was exclipsed by the rising powers of Athens and Sparta. In Athens, the inhabitants first gave the title of tyrant to Peisistratus, a relative of Solon, the Athenian lawgiver, who succeeded in 546 BC, after 2 failed attempts, to install himself as tyrant. Supported by prosperity of the pesantry and landowning interests of the plain (prospering from the rise of olive exports), and his clients from Marathon, he managed to achieve supreme power. Through an ambitious program of public works, by fostering the state cult of Athena, by encouraging the creation of festivals and supporting the Panathenaean games, in which prizes were jars of olive oil, and in his support of the Dionosia (leading to the development of Athenian drama) Peisistratus managed to maintain his personal popularity. He was followed by his sons, and with the subsequent growth of Athenian democracy, the title "tyrant" took on its familiar negative connotations. The murder of his son, the tyrant Hipparchus by Aristogeiton and Harmodios in Athens in 514 BC marked the beginning of the so-called "cult of the tyrannicides" (i.e., of killers of tyrants). Contempt for tyranny characterised this cult movement. Despite financial help from Persia, in 510 the Peisistratids were expelled by a combination of intrigue, exile and Spartan arms. The anti-tyrannical attitude became especially prevalent in Athens after 508 BC, when Cleisthenes reformed the political system so that it resembled demokratia (ancient participant democracy as opposed to the modern representative democracy).

TEXT.German: [TAB]Der Begriff der Tyrannis umschreibt eine Herrschaftsform der griechischen Antike, die besonders im Zeitraum zwischen 600 v. Chr. und 200 v. Chr. vorkam. Es handelte sich um eine Art von Alleinherrschaft, wobei man in der Regel zwei Phasen unterscheidet: die Ältere (oder Archaische) Tyrannis, die im 7. Jahrhundert v. Chr. aufkam und spätestens 461 v. Chr. endete, sowie die Jüngere Tyrannis, die gegen Ende des 5. Jahrhunderts v. Chr. aufkam und vor allem außerhalb des griechischen Mutterlandes (vor allem auf Sizilien) verbreitet war. Im Gegensatz zur Basileia (Königtum) bezeichnete der Begriff Tyrannis dabei in der Regel eine illegitime Form der Alleinherrschaft über eine Polis, in der eine monarchische Staatsform eigentlich nicht vorgesehen und mit den nomoi (Gesetzen) schwer oder gar nicht vereinbar war.
